para.text: Governs food service facilities in Maryland;

Along with COMAR 10.15.04, 15.04.01, and 15.11.11, establishes the standards for the control of Salmonella Enteritidis in shell eggs and egg-producing chickens as part of a program jointly administered by the Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Department of Agriculture; and

Is not intended to govern the food service operations in a child care center as defined in Family Law Article, §5-570, Annotated Code of Maryland, or a family day care home as defined in Family Law Article, §5-501, Annotated Code of Maryland, unless the food service operation is conducted in conjunction with another institution that is governed by this chapter.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Acceptable” means agreeable to the use or presence of equipment or a practice when standards are not developed or when developed standards are inappropriate, because the approving authority has determined that the equipment or practice conforms to principles, practices, and generally recognized standards that protect public health.
Adulterated.
“Adulterated” has the meaning stated in Health-General Article, §§21-207, 21-208, and 21-209, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Adulterated” includes food that:
Contains any poisonous or deleterious substance;
Is diseased, contaminated, filthy, putrid, or decomposed; or
Is otherwise unfit as food for human beings.
“Approved source” means a source of food or food ingredients accepted by the Department because the food or food ingredients from the source:
Are not adulterated or misbranded; and
Where required, are regulated by the approving authority.
“Approving authority” means:
Within the State, the Secretary of Health or the Secretary's designee; or
Outside the State, the agency designated in the laws of another state or country to license or permit a food establishment.
“aw” means water activity, which is:
The ratio of the water vapor pressure of a food to the vapor pressure of pure water at the same temperature; and
An index of the available, free moisture in food.
Bake Sale.
“Bake sale” means a place where only non-potentially hazardous bakery goods, including breads and pastries, are sold in conjunction with a fundraising event.
“Bake sale” does not include a place:
Where a person sells baked goods for individual profit;
From which food is commercially distributed; or
Where a potentially hazardous baked good is sold or distributed.
“Barrier” means a physical, biological, or chemical factor that retards or prevents the growth of microorganisms that are infectious or toxigenic.

“Base of operations” means a licensed food service facility that is used by the owner or operator of a mobile food service facility for food storage, potable water, safe disposal of waste and sewage, and, if necessary, utensil washing.
“Bed and breakfast” means a lodging or rooming house as defined in Public Safety Article, §9-201, Annotated Code of Maryland, that has eight rooms or fewer for rent.
“Bona fide nonprofit” means an organization having official documentation from the United States Internal Revenue Service that the organization has current tax-exempt nonprofit status.
“Caterer” means a food service facility that:
Offers catering services; or
Identifies itself as a caterer.
“Catering services” means the preparation or provision and the serving of food or drink by a food service facility for service at the provider's premises or elsewhere in connection with a:
Specific public event; or
Business or social function or affair.
“Commercially sterile” means the condition achieved by the:
Application of heat, pressure, or other energy or matter that renders a food free of:
Microorganisms capable of reproducing in the food under normal nonrefrigerated conditions of storage and distribution; and
Viable microorganisms, including spores, that may cause disease; or

Control of water activity and the application of heat, pressure, or other energy or matter that renders the food free of microorganisms capable of reproducing in the food under normal nonrefrigerated conditions of storage and distribution.
Comminuted.
“Comminuted” means reduced in size by methods including:
Chopping;
Flaking;
Grinding; or
Mincing.
“Comminuted” includes fish, meat, or a mixture of products that are reduced in size and restructured or reformulated, such as:
Gefilte fish;
Formed roast beef;
The meat used in gyros;
Ground beef; and
Sausage.
“Condiment” means a food or seasoning used to enhance the flavor of another food, including:
Mustard;
Ketchup;
Mayonnaise;
Relish;
Salt;
Pepper;
Sugar; or
Chutney.

“Consumer” means a person who is a member of the public, takes possession of food, is not functioning in the capacity of an operator of a food service facility or food processing plant, and does not offer the food for resale.
“Consumer advisory” means a written notification to consumers that:
Identifies food of animal origin that is served or sold as a ready-to-eat food or as an ingredient in a ready-to-eat food that is:
Raw;
Undercooked; or
Not otherwise processed to eliminate pathogens; and
Reminds consumers that consuming raw or undercooked meats, poultry, seafood, shellfish, or eggs may increase the risk of foodborne illness, especially if the consumer has certain medical conditions.
Continental Breakfast.
“Continental breakfast” means a meal that does not require major food preparation as specified in Regulation .28G(1) of this chapter.
“Continental breakfast” includes foods such as:
Coffee and tea;
Juice;
Cereal;
Milk and cream;
Whole fresh fruit;
Pastries;
Bread;
Donuts;
Butter and margarine; and
Jams and jellies.
“Continental breakfast” does not include foods such as:
Eggs cooked outside of the shell;
Meat; and
Fruit salad prepared on premises.
“Corrosion resistant” means the property that allows a material to maintain sanitary surface characteristics under the influence of prolonged contact with:
Food;
Cleaning compounds;
Sanitizing solutions; and
Other conditions of the environment.
“Cottage food business” means a business that:
Produces or packages cottage food products in a residential kitchen in Maryland; and
Has annual revenues from the sale of cottage food products in an amount not exceeding $50,000.
“Cottage food product” means:
A non-potentially hazardous food as specified in Regulation .27 of this chapter that is offered for sale:
Directly to a consumer from a residence, by personal delivery, by mail delivery, at a farmer’s market, or at a public event; or
To a retail food store if the cottage food product remains in the original packaging; and
A food that is not offered for sale through interstate commerce.
“County of origin” means the county in which the base of operations of a mobile food service facility is located.

“Critical control point (CCP)” means a point in the preparation or processing of food where there is a reasonable likelihood that improper control may cause, allow, or contribute to a hazard to public health.
Critical Item.
“Critical item” means a food safety requirement that if violated requires:
Immediate correction;
The cessation of some or all processing operations; or
Plant closure.
“Critical item” includes the following requirements:
Obtaining food from an approved source;
Protecting food from adulteration, spoilage, and contamination;
Restricting food workers with infection or diarrhea in accordance with COMAR 10.06.01;
Ensuring that all food workers wash hands thoroughly before touching food and utensils, and as often as needed to prevent food contamination from hand contact;
Cooling potentially hazardous foods in accordance with the requirements of this chapter;
Holding potentially hazardous foods at the hot and cold temperatures specified in this chapter;
Cooking and reheating potentially hazardous foods in accordance with the requirements of this chapter;
Providing potable hot and cold running water; and
Discharging sewage from the facility in accordance with all applicable State and local codes.

“Critical limit” means the maximum or minimum value to which a physical, biological, or chemical parameter must be controlled at a critical control point to minimize the risk that an identified potential food safety hazard may occur.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health or the Department's designee.

“Detention order” means a written notification by the approving authority to the person-in-charge of a food service facility to detain food that may be adulterated or misbranded, pending a determination of the food's status and disposition in accordance with Health-General Article, §§21-253 and 21-254, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Easily cleanable” means the property of a surface that allows the surface to:
Be readily accessible; and
Have soil and residue removed by routine cleaning methods.
“Egg carton” means a container holding up to 36 shell eggs, including overwrapped cartons and sleeves, that is used to pack shell eggs for distribution or sale to a consumer.
“Egg case” means a container that:
Is not a carton;
Holds either loose shell eggs or cartons of eggs; and
Is used to pack shell eggs for distribution or sale to a consumer.
“Employee” means:
The licensee;
An individual having supervisory or management duties;
An individual on the payroll;
A volunteer;
An individual performing work under contractual agreement; or
Any other individual working in a food service facility.
Equipment.
“Equipment” means an item, other than a utensil, that is used in the operation of a food establishment for:
Storage;
Preparation;
Display;
Washing; or
Transportation.
“Equipment” includes a:
Stove;
Oven;
Hood;
Slicer;
Grinder;
Mixer;
Scale;
Meat block;
Table;
Food shelf;
Refrigerator;
Freezer;
Sink;
Ice maker; or
Another item used in the operation of a food service facility.
“Equipment” does not include a:
Forklift truck; or
Dolly.

“Excluded organization” means a volunteer fire company or bona fide nonprofit fraternal, civic, war veterans’, religious, or charitable organization or corporation that does not serve food to the public more often than 4 days per week, except that once a year an organization may serve food to the public for up to 30 consecutive days.
Farm.
“Farm” means a place where agricultural commodities are grown, raised, or harvested for commercial purposes.
“Farm” includes a place where, for commercial purposes:
Crops are grown and harvested;
Fruit, nuts, or other agricultural commodities are harvested from trees; or
Animals are raised, fed, and managed for meat or other agricultural commodities.
Farmer's Market.
“Farmer's market” means a place where a person offers or sells one or more of the following food products directly to the public:
Raw agricultural products;
Products processed in a private home kitchen, as set forth in Regulation .27 of this chapter;
Products that are not potentially hazardous and do not require refrigeration that are processed in a food processing plant licensed and operated according to COMAR 10.15.04.19; or
Eggs in compliance with Regulation .05A(8) of this chapter.
“Farmer's market” does not include a food service facility.
“Food” means:
A substance that is used as:
Food or drink for human beings; or
A component of food or drink for human beings; or
Chewing gum or any substance that is a component of chewing gum.
“Food-contact surface” means a surface:
Of equipment and utensils with which food normally comes in contact; or
From which food may drain, drip, or splash onto a:
Food; or
Surface normally in contact with food.
“Food processing plant” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.15.04.02B.
Food Service Facility.
“Food service facility” means:
A place where food or drink is prepared for sale or service on the premises or elsewhere; or
An operation where food is served to or provided for the public with or without charge.
“Food service facility” includes:
A restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, retail market, or retail bakery outlet;

A food operation in an industry, institution, health care facility, club, school, camp, church, catering kitchen, commissary, or a similar place in which food or drink is prepared for sale or for service on the premises or elsewhere; and
A micro market licensed under Business Regulation Article, Title 17, Subtitle 17, Annotated Code of Maryland, and meeting the requirements of this chapter as a food service facility.
“Food service facility” does not include a:
Facility that offers only prepackaged foods that are not potentially hazardous as specified in §B(55)(c) of this regulation;

Kitchen in a private home where food is prepared at no charge for guests in the home, for guests at a social gathering that is not a public event, or for service to unemployed, homeless, or another disadvantaged population;
Food preparation or serving area where food is prepared or served only by an excluded organization;
Hotel, lodging, or rooming house that serves only a continental breakfast;
Farmer’s market or a public event where food products as specified in §B(30)(a) of this regulation are sold;
Bake sale where only non-potentially hazardous bakery goods, including breads and pastries, are sold in conjunction with a fundraising event; or
Cottage food business.
Game Animal.
“Game animal” means an animal:
That is food for human beings; and
That is not classified as cattle, sheep, swine, goat, mule, or other equine.
“Game animal” includes:
Reindeer;
Elk;
Deer;
Antelope;
Water buffalo;
Bison;
Rabbit;
Squirrel;
Opossum;
Raccoon;
Nutria;
Muskrat;
Bear; and
Nonaquatic reptiles such as land snakes.
“Game animal” does not include ratites such as:
Ostrich;
Emu; and
Rhea.
“Hazard” means a biological, chemical, or physical property that may be detrimental to public health.

“Hazard analysis critical control point (HACCP) plan” means a written plan that delineates the procedures for maintaining control of potentially hazardous food at the critical control points of food preparation or processing.
Health Care Facility.
“Health care facility” means:
A hospital, as defined in Health-General Article, §19-301, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A related institution, as defined in Health-General Article, §19-301, Annotated Code of Maryland;
An ambulatory surgical facility or center as defined in Health-General Article, §19-114, Annotated Code of Maryland;

An inpatient facility that is organized primarily to help in the rehabilitation of disabled individuals, through an integrated program of medical and other services provided under competent professional supervision;
A home health agency, as defined in Health-General Article, §19-401, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A hospice facility, as defined in Health-General Article, §19-901, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Another health institution, service, or program for which Health-General Article, §19-114(d)(1)(ix), Annotated Code of Maryland, requires a certificate of need.
“Health care facility” does not include the facilities, institutions, and offices set forth in Health-General Article, §19-114(d)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Hermetically sealed container” means a container that:
Is secure against the entry of microorganisms; and
Maintains the commercial sterility of the contents after processing.
“Juice” means:
The aqueous liquid expressed or extracted from one or more fruits or vegetables;
Purees of the edible portion of one or more fruits or vegetables; or
Any concentrate of the liquid or puree as referenced in §B(40)(a) and (b) of this regulation.

“License” means the authority to operate a food service facility within the State in accordance with this chapter and Health-General Article, Title 21, Subtitles 1, 2, and 3, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Loose eggs” means shell eggs not contained in a carton.
“Lot designation” means a method of marking packed or packaged shell eggs to enable the packer and the approving authority to trace the eggs to the flock that produced the eggs.
Major Food Allergen.
“Major food allergen” means:
Milk;
Egg;
Fish such as bass, flounder, or cod;
Crustacea such as crab, lobster, or shrimp;
Tree nuts such as almonds, pecans, or walnuts;
Wheat;
Peanuts;
Soybeans; and
A food ingredient that contains protein derived from milk, egg, fish, tree nuts, wheat, peanuts, or soybeans.
“Major food allergen” does not include:
A highly refined oil derived from a food specified in §B(44)(a) of this regulation and any ingredient derived from a highly refined oil; or
An ingredient that is exempt in regard to food allergen labeling requirements under the petition or notification process specified in 21 U.S.C. §343(w)(6) and (7).
“Micro market” means an unstaffed, self-checkout retail food service facility that:
Includes one or more micro market displays;
Has an automated payment kiosk or other device designed to accept electronic payments that is operated by the consumer;
Is located indoors and within a separate business; and
Is generally accessible only to individuals within the building in which the food service facility is located.
“Micro market display” means the place where the food being sold by a micro market is displayed, including:
An open rack;
A refrigerator or a refrigerated cooler;
A freezer;
A vending machine;
A beverage dispenser; or
A single-serve coffee brewer.
“Misbranded” has the meaning stated in Health-General Article, §21-210, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Mobile Food Service Facility.

“Mobile food service facility” means a food service facility that is a mechanically, electrically, manually, or otherwise propelled vehicle operating on land or water that moves as part of its routine operation to:
Change location for sales;
Obtain food and other supplies;
Fill potable water supply holding tanks;
Empty wastewater holding tanks; or
Provide for the cleaning and sanitization of equipment and utensils.
“Mobile food service facility” does not include a food service facility that is able to be moved but does not move routinely for a purpose set forth in §B(46)(a) of this regulation.
“Mobile reciprocity license” means a license issued to a mobile food service facility that:
Is operating in the jurisdiction;
Is operating within 90 miles of its base of operations; and
Holds a valid license from the county of origin.
“Non-potentially hazardous food” means food named or described in §B(55)(c) of this regulation.
“On-farm food service facility” means a temporary food service facility that:
Is located on a farm;
Serves only those foods approved by the Department, based on a:
Review of the facility, equipment, and processing hazards; and
Determination that these foods can be prepared safely and in a manner that conforms to applicable laws and regulations; and
Operates during a period of time of not more than 30 consecutive days with up to two renewals in a 1-year period.
“Package” means a bottle, can, carton, bag, or wrapped container.
“Packer” means a person who places shell eggs in the original case, carton, or container that is used to hold eggs for:
Distribution; or
Sale to a consumer.
“Person” has the meaning stated in Health-General Article, §§1-101 and 21-101, including:
An operator of a facility that is owned by the State or local unit of government; or
A State or local unit of government if the State or local unit of government is the operator of the facility.
“Person-in-charge” means:
The licensee; or
Another person responsible for the operation of a food service facility.
“pH” means the symbol for the negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration in gram equivalents per liter of solution where:
pH values from 0 to 7 indicate acidity;
pH values from 7 to14 indicate alkalinity; and
The pH value for pure distilled water, regarded as neutral, is 7.
“Portable” means that equipment:
Can be easily moved because the equipment is:
Small in size and weighs 80 pounds or less;
Mounted on casters, gliders, or rollers; or
Provided with a mechanical means of safely tilting for cleaning; and
Has one of the following:
No utility connection;
A utility connection that disconnects quickly; or
A flexible utility connection line long enough to permit the equipment to be moved for thorough cleaning.
Potentially Hazardous Food.
“Potentially hazardous food” means a natural or synthetic food that requires temperature control because the food is in a form capable of supporting:
The rapid and progressive growth of infectious or toxigenic microorganisms;
The growth and toxin production of Clostridium botulinum; or
In raw shell eggs, the growth of Salmonella Enteritidis.
“Potentially hazardous food” includes:
A food of animal origin that is raw or heat-treated;
A food of plant origin that is heat-treated;
Raw seed sprouts;
Cut melons;
Cut raw tomatoes;
Garlic and oil mixtures that support growth as specified in §B(55)(a)(i) and (ii) of this regulation; and
Cut leafy greens.
“Potentially hazardous food” does not include a:
Hard-boiled shell egg that has been air-cooled with the shell intact;
Food with an aw value of 0.85 or less;
Food with a pH level of 4.6 or below when measured at 75°F;
Commercially sterile food in a hermetically sealed container; or

Food for which laboratory evidence demonstrates that the rapid and progressive growth of infectious and toxigenic microorganisms or the growth of Salmonella Enteritidis in eggs or Clostridium botulinum cannot occur, such as a food that has an aw or a pH that is above the levels specified in §B(55)(c)(ii)and(iii) of this regulation or that may contain a preservative, other barrier to the growth of microorganisms, or a combination of barriers that inhibit the growth of microorganisms.
“Poultry” means a:
Domesticated bird whether live or dead including a:
Chicken;
Turkey;
Duck;
Goose;
Guinea;
Ratite; or
Squab; and
Migratory waterfowl or game bird whether live or dead, including a:
Pheasant;
Partridge;
Quail; or
Grouse.
“Premises” means the physical food service facility and the contiguous land or property under the control of the operator or the licensee.
“Principal display panel” means the part of a container that is most likely to be displayed, presented, shown, or examined under customary conditions of display for retail sale.
“Priority assessment” means an evaluation of risk in a food service facility using the parameters established by the Department in Regulation .33C of this chapter.
Public Event.
“Public event” means an event or festival that is a planned gathering that is:
Open to the public; and
Regulated by the State or local jurisdiction in which the planned gathering takes place.
“Public event” includes an event or festival:
Attended by individuals from the general public whether or not a fee is charged; or
Advertised with fliers, banners, newspaper articles, radio or television announcements, or on an Internet website as being open to the public.
“Public event” does not include a:
Private party;
An event restricted to organization members; or
Another event that restricts the general public from attending.
“Raw agricultural product” means a whole, unprocessed agricultural product supplied directly from the farm on which it was produced, including:
Grains;
Flowers;
Herbs;
Nuts;
Fruits;
Vegetables; and
Honey.
Ready-to-Eat Food.
“Ready-to-eat food” means food in a form that is edible without washing, cooking, or additional preparation by the food service facility or the consumer.
“Ready-to-eat food” includes:
Potentially hazardous food that is cooked to the temperature and time required for a specific food as set forth in Regulation .10 of this chapter;
Raw fruits and vegetables that are washed and cut;
Whole, raw fruits and vegetables that are presented for consumption without need for further washing, such as at a buffet; and
A food presented for consumption for which further washing or cooking is not required and from which rinds, peels, husks, or shells are removed.
“Reconditioned” means reprocessing a food using an approved method that results in a food that is safe, wholesome, and free from contamination.
“Reconstituted” means water or other liquid has been restored to a food that was previously dehydrated.
Reduced Oxygen Packaged.
“Reduced oxygen packaged” means that a food was packaged so that the amount of oxygen in the package is below that found in the surrounding atmosphere due to the:
Mechanical evacuation of oxygen;
Displacement of oxygen with one or more gases; or
Reduction of the oxygen content by other means.
“Reduced oxygen packaged” includes food that is:
Vacuum packaged;
Modified atmosphere packaged; and
Controlled atmosphere packaged.
“Refrigerated food” means a food that:
Is not shelf stable;
Must be refrigerated to:
Retard the growth of spoilage or pathogenic microorganisms; and
Prevent the production of microbial toxins; or
Is labeled by the manufacturer with a statement indicating that the product is to be kept refrigerated.
“Registration” means the process by which the Maryland Department of Agriculture grants the authority to a packer within the State to provide shell eggs for human consumption.
“Registration number” means the number that the Maryland Department of Agriculture assigns a packer.
“Retail food manufacturing” means the manufacturing of food in a food service facility for wholesale distribution.
Retail Food Store.
“Retail food store” means a licensed food service facility that sells prepackaged food items either fresh, refrigerated, frozen, or shelf-stable.
“Retail food store” includes a grocery store, convenience store, retail market, retail bakery, or food cooperative.

“Retail food store” does not include a restaurant, mobile food service facility, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order café, luncheonette, tavern sandwich shop, produce stand that only offers whole, uncut fresh fruits and vegetables, or establishment that offers only pre-packaged non-potentially hazardous foods.

“Sanitization” means a heat or chemical treatment on cleaned food contact surfaces that is sufficient to yield a 99.999 percent reduction of the number of representative disease microorganisms of public health significance.
“Seasonal farmer’s market producer sampling food service facility” means a facility that:
Serves only foods that are prepared and offered as samples by a producer of a farm product at a farmer’s market or a public event, such as:
Farm products as specified in §B(30)(a) of this regulation; or
Farm products that have been inspected, licensed, or certified for food safety by the Maryland Department of Agriculture;
Serves food only produced by the licensee;
Serves only those foods approved by the Department, based on a:
Review of the facility, equipment, and processing hazards; and
Determination that these foods can be prepared safely and in a manner that conforms to applicable laws and regulations; and
Operates during a period of time of not more than a 1-year period from the date of issuance or renewal of the license.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Health or the Secretary's designee.
“Semi-permanent food service facility” means a facility that:
Is built at a location other than where it operates;
Is transported as a complete unit that does not require a building permit to install on the location at which it operates;
Has no indoor seating for patrons;
When serving cooked food, serves only foods cooked for immediate service; and
Is not a mobile food service facility as specified in §B(46) of this regulation.
“Service animal” has the meaning stated in Human Services Article, §7-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Shell eggs” means raw eggs produced by chickens for human consumption.
“Shellfish” means all species of:
Oysters, clams, or mussels, whether:
Shucked or in the shell;
Raw, including post-harvest processed;
Frozen or unfrozen; and
Whole or in part; and
Scallops in any form, except when the final product is the adductor muscle only.
Single Service Article.
“Single service article” means an article designed, fabricated, and intended for one-time consumer use.
“Single service article” includes a:
Utensil;
Cup;
Plate;
Stirrer;
Napkin;
Straw;
Toothpick;
Food container;
Place mat;
Food package; or
Similar item.
Single Use Article.
“Single use article” means an article intended by the manufacturer for one-time use by the preparer of the food.
“Single use article” includes a:
Bulk food container;
Utensil;
Formed aluminum pie pan;
Jar;
Plastic bucket; or
Similar item.
Special Food Service Facility.
“Special food service facility” means a food service facility for which the Department provides exceptions to certain regulations because of the nature of one or more of the following:
Design and operation of the facility;
Food preparation or service methods; or
Limited length of time that the facility operates in association with special events.
“Special food service facility” includes:
A bed and breakfast that serves hot meals;
A mobile unit;
A temporary food service facility;
A semi-permanent food service facility;
An on-farm food service facility; or
A seasonal farmer’s market producer sampling food service facility.
Tableware.
“Tableware” means multi-use eating, drinking, and serving utensils.
“Tableware” includes:
Knives;
Forks;
Spoons;
Bowls;
Cups;
Serving dishes;
Tumblers; and
Plates.
“Temporary food service facility” means a food service facility that operates at a fixed location for up to 30 consecutive days in conjunction with a:
Fair;
Carnival;
Public exhibition;
Construction project;
Recreational facility;
Fundraising event; or
Similar gathering.
“Time-only” means using time instead of time in conjunction with temperature as the sole means of food protection for a potentially hazardous food.
“Undercooked” means a potentially hazardous food that is not cooked to the minimum internal temperature and for the specified holding time specified in Regulation .10A of this chapter.
“Utensil” means tableware or a food-contact implement used in the storage, preparation, dispensing, or serving of food.
“Vending machine” means a self-service device that dispenses either packaged or unpackaged food.
“Warewashing” means the cleaning and sanitizing of food-contact surfaces of equipment or utensils.
Whole Muscle, Intact Beefsteak.

“Whole muscle, intact beefsteak” means a beefsteak cut from whole muscle beef that has not been penetrated in a way that may allow infectious or toxigenic microorganisms to be introduced into the interior of the meat.
“Whole-muscle, intact beefsteak” does not include meat that has been:
Injected;
Mechanically tenderized;
Reconstructed; or
Scored.
In this chapter, the following documents are incorporated by reference.
Documents Incorporated.
21 CFR, as amended;
9 CFR, as amended; and
21 U.S.C. §343, as amended.
Food served to the public is:
Wholesome and free from contamination;
Not adulterated;
Safe for human consumption;
Obtained from an approved source; and
If in packaged form, labeled in accordance with:
COMAR 10.15.04; and
This chapter;
Eggs and egg products comply with Regulation .05 of this chapter;
Milk and milk products are not sold or served unless they are produced, processed, stored, transported, and distributed in accordance with COMAR 10.15.06 and COMAR 10.15.09, including:
Fluid milk;
Other fluid dairy products;
Manufactured milk products; and
Reconstituted dry milk or dry milk products used only for:
Instant desserts;
Whipped products; and
Cooking and baking purposes;
Frozen desserts including ice cream, soft frozen desserts, ice milk, sherbets, ices, gelato, and frozen dessert mix are manufactured and sold in accordance with COMAR 10.15.05;
Shellfish:
Are obtained from an approved source;
Are from a firm listed in the “Interstate Certified Shellfish Shippers List”;
Are processed, handled, packed, labeled, and identified in accordance with COMAR 10.15.07;
Containers are identified with a tag or label as set forth in COMAR 10.15.07; and
Tags are maintained on the premises for 90 calendar days after a container of shellfish is emptied to identify readily the source of the shellfish, by:
Recording the date on the tag or label when the last shellfish from the container is sold or served;
Using an approved record keeping system that:
Keeps the tags or labels in chronological order; and
Preserves source identification if tags or labels are removed from the container; and
Ensuring that shellfish from one tagged or labeled container is not mixed with shellfish from another container if the tags or labels are removed from the container.
Crab meat is processed, handled, and packed in accordance with COMAR 10.15.02;
Seafood is processed, handled, and packed in accordance with COMAR 10.15.10;
Meat and poultry have been inspected for wholesomeness by the approving authority; and
Ice is:
Made:
From a potable water supply;
In an ice-making machine that:
Meets the standards in Regulation .15 of this chapter; and
Is located, installed, operated, and maintained to prevent contamination;
If not manufactured on site, obtained from an approved source;
Handled, transported, and stored in a manner that precludes contamination; and
Not reused.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Only clean, whole Grade A or higher grade eggs with shell intact and without cracks, or pasteurized eggs or egg products, are used;
An invoice or other equivalent record is obtained from the supplier for each delivery of shell eggs;
The invoice or equivalent record required in §A(2) of this regulation contains the following information written in English:
Name and address of the seller and buyer;
Date of delivery;
Grade and size of eggs delivered; and
Quantity of eggs sold in number by grade and size;
When loose eggs are distributed, offered for sale, or sold directly to a consumer in Maryland:
A daily record is maintained that shows the lot designation of the shell eggs for each packer;
A placard is displayed that:
Is legible and printed in block letters not less than 3/8 inch in height;
Is a minimum size of 4-1/4 inches by 6 inches;
Plainly and conspicuously displays the eggs' grade term, size (weight), and lot designation; and
Is placed on or near the eggs; and
Egg cartons are labeled in accordance with §A(9), (10), and (12) of this regulation;
All egg invoices, daily records, or other equivalent records are kept on file for a minimum of 90 days;
Upon request, the approving authority is granted access to copy and verify, at any reasonable time, records relating to the sale and purchase of shell eggs;

Except as provided in Regulation .10 of this chapter, only pasteurized eggs and egg products are used when serving eggs or foods prepared with eggs that have not been heated adequately to kill Salmonella Enteritidis;
All shell eggs accepted for delivery, used, or provided to the consumer are:
Produced by flocks that are certified to be in compliance with COMAR 15.11.11;
Supplied by a registered packer as provided in COMAR 15.04.01; and
Pasteurized or otherwise heat-treated to kill Salmonella Enteriditis if Salmonella Enteriditis is isolated from a flock in Maryland as determined by testing procedures contained in COMAR 15.11.11;
All egg cartons of shell eggs accepted for delivery, used, or provided to the consumer are labeled on the principal display or information panel with:
Legible stamping in permanent ink;
The following information at a minimum type size of 1/16 of an inch:
The packer's or distributor's name and address;
The packer's registration number;
The lot designation of the eggs; and

A safe handling statement with the words "safe handling instructions" in bold capital letters and the statement "To prevent illness from bacteria: keep eggs refrigerated, cook eggs until yolks are firm, and cook foods containing eggs thoroughly." set off in a box by hairlines;
The following information at a minimum type size of 1/4 of an inch:
The identity of the product as eggs; and
The word "grade" and the grade term (AA or A) and size (weight) of the eggs; and

The net quantity of eggs in weight or numerical count in at least the minimum type size permitted based on the space available for labeling as set forth in §B of this regulation, with the minimum type size measurement determined by:
The height of type of printing by measuring the height of the lower case letter "o" or its equivalent when mixed upper and lower case letters are used; or
The height of the upper case letters when only upper case letters are used;

If the safe handling statement does not appear on the principal display panel or the front information panel, a separate statement that eggs be kept refrigerated is printed on either the principal display panel or the front of the information panel;
The same information in at least the same minimum type size that is required on an egg carton is printed on the top of an egg case or any side of an egg case; and
The grade term and size (weight) on an egg carton is not abbreviated.

section.heading: Food Protection During Storage, Service, and Transport.

para.text: At all times:
Food is:
Not adulterated; and
Protected from contamination during storage, preparation, display, service, and transportation;
The internal temperature of a food is maintained according to the requirements of this chapter to preclude the growth of pathogenic bacteria and other microorganisms that could cause spoilage;
Except during necessary periods of preparation and service, a potentially hazardous food is refrigerated or held hot as set forth in §B(7) of this regulation;
When storing and holding food:
Facilities used for hot or cold potentially hazardous food are provided a temperature-measuring device that is:
Graduated and accurate to plus or minus 2°F;
Calibrated annually or more frequently;
Located in the:
Coldest area of equipment where hot foods are stored; and
Warmest area of equipment where cold foods are stored; and
Easily readable;
Except for metal beverage containers and cased food packaged in cans, glass, or other waterproof containers stored as provided in §B(3) of this regulation, containers of food are stored:
Off the floor;
18 inches above the floor or higher if food is exposed;
On clean racks, dollies, or other clean surfaces; and
In a manner that will protect from splash and other contamination;
When metal beverage containers and cased food in cans, glass, or other waterproof containers are stored on the floor:
The floor is maintained in a clean and sanitary condition;
The storage:
Is temporary such as for floor displays;
Does not interfere with the flow of food or personnel; and
Does not afford harborage for rodents or insects;
In refrigeration units, the food is placed to permit free circulation of cold air;
Except where food packaging prevents the entry of water, packaged food is not stored in contact with water or un-drained ice;
Food is not stored in locker rooms, toilet rooms, dressing rooms, garbage rooms, or mechanical rooms;
Except as provided in §B(8)—(13) of this regulation, the internal temperature of a potentially hazardous food is kept at 41°F or less or 135°F or greater;
If pasteurized crab meat, the crab meat’s internal temperature is maintained at 41°F or less;
If potentially hazardous reduced oxygen packaged products, the reduced oxygen packaged food's internal temperature is maintained at:
38°F or less if refrigeration is the only barrier to control the growth of Clostridium botulinum; or
At a lower temperature if a lower temperature is specified by the food manufacturer;
If shell eggs and shellfish, the eggs and shellfish are stored, displayed, and transported under refrigeration at an ambient temperature of 45°F or less;
Except for the service of foods such as ice cream and frozen desserts, frozen food is received and stored frozen;
If a whole roast cooked and cooled in accordance with Regulations .10 and .11 of this chapter, the roast is held at an internal temperature of 130°F or above; and
Using holding temperatures and times other than those specified in this section, the holding temperatures and times are:
Scientifically proven to be effective in preventing the growth of foodborne pathogens;
Incorporated into an HACCP plan; and
Submitted to and approved by the Department based on a review that indicates compliance with §B(13)(a) and (b) of this regulation;
While displaying and serving food:
Except as provided in §C(3) of this regulation, a potentially hazardous cold food that is placed on display is:
Pre-chilled to an internal temperature of 41°F or below;
Rapidly re-chilled to an internal temperature of 41ºF or below if the food has exceeded 41ºF for a verifiable period of not more than 4 hours; or
Discarded if:
The food has exceeded 41°F or more for more than 4 hours; or
The time the food has been out of temperature is not verifiable;
Except as provided in §§B(12) and (13) and C(3) of this regulation, a potentially hazardous hot food that is placed on display is:
Cooked according to Regulation .10 of this chapter;
Rapidly re-heated to an internal temperature of 165ºF or above if the food was below 135ºF for a verifiable period of not more than 4 hours; and
Discarded if:
The food was below 135°F for more than 4 hours; or
The time the food has been out of temperature is not verifiable;
A potentially hazardous bakery product that is stored at room temperature:
Is manufactured, packaged, and labeled with a sell-by date only in an approved food processing plant meeting the requirements set forth in COMAR 10.15.04;
Remains in the original package until sold to a consumer; and
Is not offered for human consumption following expiration of the sell-by date;
Except as provided in §C(5) of this regulation, raw unpackaged food of animal origin is not offered for consumer self-service;
Raw unpackaged foods of animal origin offered for consumer self-service are offered only:
At buffets or salad bars that serve foods of animal origin such as sushi or raw shellfish;
When the foods of animal origin are ready-to-cook individual portions for immediate cooking and consumption on premises, such as for Mongolian barbecue; or
Frozen if shell-on shrimp and lobster;
When uncovered food is placed on display in food operations, including buffets and cafeterias, the ready-to-eat food is protected by:
Physical guards;
Separation from potential contaminants; or
Other effective methods acceptable to the approving authority;
During pauses in food preparation or dispensing, utensils such as scoops, spoons, and dippers are stored:
In a running water dipper well that provides a volume of fresh potable water sufficient to maintain the utensil in a sanitary condition;
In hot water that is maintained at 135°F or above;
With the handles above the top of the food in an open container;
On a clean portion of the food preparation or cooking equipment, which has been cleaned and sanitized as set forth in Regulation .16 of this chapter; or
In a clean, protected location if the utensils are used with a food that is not potentially hazardous;
Sugar, condiments, seasonings, and dressings are provided for self-service in individual packages or dispensed by methods that protect the food;
Except for packaged non-potentially hazardous foods with the wrapping intact, portions of food once served to a customer are not served again; and

Except for drinking cups reused by self-service consumers in a manner to prevent cross-contamination, employees and self-service customers do not reuse soiled tableware, including single service articles to:
Provide second portions or refills; or
Obtain additional food from display and serving equipment;
During the transportation of food:
Except as provided in §B(8)—(13) of this regulation, the internal temperature of a potentially hazardous food is maintained at 41°F or below or 135°F or above;
From a food service facility to another location, the requirements set forth in §A(2) of this regulation are met;
Frozen food is maintained frozen; and
Food is in covered containers or completely wrapped or packaged to protect against contamination; and
During the preparation, storage, or service of food:
Unsafe or adulterated food is discarded or reconditioned according to an approved procedure by the approving authority;
Food that is not from an approved source as specified under Regulation .04 of this chapter is discarded;
Ready-to-eat food that may have been contaminated by an employee who has been restricted or excluded as specified under Regulation .14A or B of this chapter is discarded; and
Food shall be discarded if it is contaminated by employees, consumers, or other persons through:
Contact with their hands;
Bodily discharges, such as nasal or oral discharges; or
Other means.

section.heading: Food Protection During Outdoor Preparation and Service.

para.text: During the use of outdoor cooking equipment, such as a barbeque grill, at a food service facility:
Equipment:
Is used only at the food service facility for service to patrons;
Is located:
On an impermeable surface;
In close proximity to the food preparation area of the food service facility; and
Away from parking areas, dumpsters, and patron entrances; and
Meets the requirements set forth in Regulation .15 of this chapter;
Food is:
Prepared for outdoor cooking inside the food service facility; and
Protected from contamination during cooking and service; and
When preparing beverages outdoors:
Overhead protection is provided;
Protection from contamination during storage is provided for ingredients, including:
Ice;
Drink mixes; and
Condiments;
Containers are protected from contamination during storage; and
Other than when only beer, wine, or soda is offered, a hand washing sink is provided in accordance with Regulation .18K and L of this chapter.

section.heading: Use of Time-Only with Potentially Hazardous Food.

para.text: The approving authority may approve the use of time-only, rather than time in conjunction with temperature, for food protection as set forth in §B of this regulation.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Before using time-only while holding or preparing a potentially hazardous food:
A written request is submitted to and approved by the approving authority for a specific food under specific conditions of preparation and service that includes:
A record-keeping procedure that can verify safety intervention steps; and
Procedures for marking or otherwise identifying the food with the time by which it is to be either used or discarded; and
The procedures for time-only are included in the food service facility's HACCP plan as a critical control point;
Except as otherwise approved by the approving authority, the maximum time limit under time-only control is 4 hours for a:
Raw, working supply of potentially hazardous food during preparation, after which time the food is cooked or discarded; and
Ready-to-eat potentially hazardous food held for immediate consumption, after which time the food not served is discarded;
Food has an initial temperature of:
41°F or less upon removal from refrigeration; or
135°F or more upon removal from cooking equipment; and
Food that has been protected using time-only control is not served in a health care facility.

section.heading: Food Preparation — Temperature and Cross-Contamination Control.

para.text: Food temperature measuring devices are:
Used to monitor the temperature of potentially hazardous foods;
Graduated and accurate within plus or minus 2°F;
Calibrated annually or more frequently; and
Cleaned and sanitized between uses in different foods to prevent cross-contamination;
The storage, thawing, cooking, cooling, reheating, and holding of a food:
Are safe; and
Comply with this chapter;
When a recipe in which more than one egg is broken and the eggs are combined and not prepared for immediate service:
The mixture is stored under refrigeration at all times before cooking;
The process is included in the food service facility's HACCP plan as a critical control point; and
The mixture containing eggs is cooked to a minimum internal temperature of 155°F for 15 seconds;
Potentially hazardous food is thawed:
In refrigerated units so that the temperature of the food does not exceed 41°F;
Under potable running water that is at or below 70°F with sufficient force to agitate and float off loose particles;
In a microwave oven only when the food will be immediately cooked in the microwave oven or immediately transferred to conventional cooking facilities as part of a continuous cooking process;
If a potentially hazardous reduced oxygen packaged food:
In the food’s airtight package at or below 41°F;
At a lower temperature if specified by the manufacturer; or
If fish or seafood, completely removed from the reduced oxygen environment or package prior to thawing;
As part of a conventional cooking process; or
By another method acceptable to the approving authority that has been scientifically proven to the approving authority to prevent the bacteriological, physical, or chemical contamination of food;
Employees prevent contact of exposed, ready-to-eat food with their bare hands by using:
Gloves as specified under Regulation .14J of this chapter;
Utensils such as:
Tongs;
Spatulas;
Deli tissue; or
Automatic dispensing equipment; and
Cross-contamination is prevented by:
Not allowing contact between ready-to-eat and raw foods;
Storing and holding food so that:
Ready-to-eat food is located above or otherwise segregated from raw food; and
A food is protected from plumbing leaks and condensate drippage;
Using separate utensils and work surfaces for ready-to-eat food and foods requiring further preparation;
Cleaning and sanitizing utensils and work surfaces between uses;
Excluding sick workers from food handling in accordance with Regulation .14A and B of this chapter; and
Washing raw fruits and vegetables thoroughly to remove soil and other contaminants before cutting, cooking, or serving, with:
Water; or
Chemicals intended specifically for washing or peeling whole fruits and vegetables as specified in 21 CFR §173.315.

Except as provided in §§B—D of this regulation, the person-in-charge shall ensure that potentially hazardous food is cooked to the minimum internal temperature and for the specified holding time as follows:
Chart 1. Summary of Minimum Cooking and Reheating Food Temperatures and Holding Times.

para.text: A minimum internal temperature of 145°F for 15 seconds for:
Shell eggs prepared for immediate service;
Fish;
Meat; and
All other potentially hazardous food not specified in §A(3)—(7) of this regulation;
A minimum internal temperature of 155°F for 15 seconds or as specified in §A(1) of this regulation for:
Shell eggs not prepared for immediate service;
Ratites;
Comminuted fish and meats;
Game animals commercially raised for food; and
Injected meats;
A minimum internal temperature of 130°F for 112 minutes or as specified in §A(1) of this chapter for:
Whole or corned beef; and
Pork and cured pork roasts;
A minimum internal temperature of 165°F for 15 seconds for:
Poultry;
Stuffed meat, pasta, or poultry;
Exotic bird species;
Wild game animals; and
Stuffing containing fish, meat, or poultry;
A minimum internal temperature of 165°F and held for 2 minutes after removing from the oven for raw animal foods that are cooked in a microwave oven; and
A minimum internal temperature of 135°F for fruits and vegetables cooked for hot holding.

The Department may approve cooking times and temperatures other than those specified in §A of this regulation, if the cooking times and temperatures are scientifically proven to the Department to be as effective in killing foodborne pathogens as those specified in §A of this regulation.
The person-in-charge may serve a consumer:
Undercooked seared beefsteak when:
Only whole muscle, intact beefsteak, is prepared;
The meat is seared continuously on both top and bottom utilizing a heating environment that:
Imparts a temperature at the surface of the intact steak of at least 145°F for 15 seconds; and
Achieves a cooked color change on all external surfaces; and
A HACCP plan specifically developed for undercooked seared beefsteak is submitted and approved by the approving authority; and
A food that is cooked, cooled, and then refrigerated in accordance with this chapter, such as roast beef for a sandwich, cold or warmed to any desired temperature for immediate consumption.
A health care facility may not serve a raw or undercooked animal food.
Repealed.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that a consumer advisory is issued when an animal food, such as beef, eggs, fish, lamb, pork, poultry, or shellfish, is served raw or undercooked by:
Providing a written notification on:
A menu or brochure;
A deli case or menu board;
A label statement;
A table tent or placard; or
Another written means that is visible and legible to the consumer;
Identifying food items on the items set forth in §F(1) of this regulation with an asterisk to a footnote that states the item:
Is served raw;
Is served undercooked;
May be cooked to order upon specific consumer request; or
Contains raw or undercooked ingredients; and
Providing this written statement: "Consuming raw or undercooked animal foods may increase your risk of contracting a foodborne illness, especially if you have certain medical conditions."

section.heading: Food Preparation — Cooling and Reheating of Potentially Hazardous Foods.

para.text: A potentially hazardous cooked food’s internal temperature is cooled from 135°F to 70°F within 2 hours and from 70°F to 41°F or less within an additional 4 hours;
A potentially hazardous food for cold service, such as a reconstituted food, salad, or canned meat, is cooled to an internal temperature of 41°F within 4 hours;
Cooling of potentially hazardous food is accomplished using one or a combination of the following methods:
Refrigerate in shallow pans with food not over 3 inches deep;
Reduce food mass by separating foods into smaller or thinner portions;
Use rapid cooling equipment;
Use ice water baths combined with frequent stirring;
Use containers that facilitate heat transfer;
Add ice made from potable water as an ingredient;
Refrigerate loosely covered or allow the food to remain uncovered until cooled if the food is protected from overhead contamination; or
Another effective method acceptable to the approving authority based on applicable state and local laws, regulations, and ordinances; and
Potentially hazardous food is reheated:
Within 2 hours to a minimum internal temperature of 165°F for 15 seconds for food that is cooked, cooled, and refrigerated before being placed into hot food holding equipment;

Within 2 hours to a minimum internal temperature of 135°F for ready-to-eat food taken from a commercially processed, hermetically sealed container or from an intact package from a food processing plant that is inspected by a food regulatory authority for hot holding;
Using the same time and temperature conditions specified in Regulation .10A of this chapter for initial cooking for remaining unsliced portions of roasts for hot holding; and

Within 2 hours or less, to a minimum internal temperature of 165°F for 15 seconds in a microwave oven for hot holding and then stirred, covered, and allowed to stand covered for 2 minutes after reheating.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Except as specified in §B of this regulation, each item of packaged food has a label containing the following information:
The common name of the food or a descriptive identity statement;
If made from two or more ingredients:
A list of ingredients in descending order of prominence by weight; and
A declaration of artificial color or flavor and chemical preservatives;
An accurate declaration of the quantity of the package contents by weight in both metric and English units;
The name and place of business of the manufacturer, packer, or distributor;
Except as exempted in 21 U.S.C. §343(q)(3)—(5), the nutrition labeling specified in 21 CFR Part 101 and 9 CFR Part 317; and
The name of the food source for each major food allergen that is contained in the food unless the food source is already part of the common or usual name of the respective ingredient;
The use of canthaxanthin as a color additive in salmonid fish is disclosed by written means, such as a counter card;
Bulk food available for consumer self-dispensing is prominently labeled with the following information in plain view of the consumer:
The manufacturer's label that was provided with the food; or
A card, sign, or other method of notification that includes the information specified in §A(1)(a), (b), and (f) of this regulation.
A food service facility may offer for sale bulk, unpackaged foods such as bakery products and unpackaged foods that are portioned to consumer specification without a label if:
A health, nutrient, or other claim relating to the unpackaged food is not made on a card or sign; and
The food is manufactured or prepared on the premises of the food service facility or at another food service facility owned by the same person.

section.heading: Food Protection from Poisonous or Toxic Materials.

para.text: Except for packaged poisonous or toxic products offered in their unopened original containers for retail sale, only poisonous or toxic materials needed to maintain sanitary conditions and to sanitize equipment and utensils are located in a food or food utensil area;
A container of a poisonous or toxic material is:
Kept in the original bulk container before use;
Prominently and distinctively marked or labeled for easy identification; and
Used according to the manufacturer's directions;
When not in use, poisonous or toxic materials are stored in a:
Cabinet used for no other purpose; or
Room not used for food storage, food preparation, or equipment and utensil washing or storage;
A bactericide, cleaning compound, or other compound intended for use on food-contact surfaces is not:
Stored in the same cabinet with an insecticide, rodenticide, or other poisonous or toxic material; or
Used or stored in a way that will leave a toxic residue on food-contact surfaces;
A poisonous or toxic material is not used or stored in a way that will:
Contaminate:
Food; or
Food equipment; or
Constitute a potential hazard to:
Employees; or
Customers;
A medication is not stored in a food storage, preparation, processing, or service area;
First aid supplies are stored in a way that prevents contamination of:
Food; or
Food-contact surfaces; and
A container previously used to store poisonous or toxic materials is not used to store, transport, or dispense:
Food; or
Items that will come into contact with food.
As set forth in COMAR 10.06.01.06E, a food handler does not serve or handle food intended for public consumption if the food handler:
Has any of the following diseases:
Diarrhea caused by Entamoeba histolytica;
Cholera;
Disease causing diarrhea, unless physician-certified as noninfectious;
E. coli O157:H7;
Hepatitis A;
Diarrhea caused by Salmonella;
Shigellosis;
Streptococcal infection caused by group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus; or
Typhoid fever; or
Is a carrier of Salmonella Typhi;
An employee experiencing persistent sneezing, coughing, or a runny nose that causes discharges from the eyes, nose, or mouth does not work with:
Exposed food;
Clean equipment, utensils, and linens; or
Unwrapped single service or single use articles;
An employee who has a disease that may be transmissible through food reports the condition to the person-in-charge;
The approving authority is notified when an employee of a food service facility is known to have or is suspected of having a disease that is transmissible by food;
An employee washes hands and exposed arm areas thoroughly with soap and warm water:
Before handling:
Exposed foods; or
Food-contact surfaces;
Before starting work;
As often as required to remove soil and contamination;
After using toilet facilities; and
Before and between glove use;
An employee washes hands, exposed portions of the arms, between the fingers, and underneath the fingernails:
With a cleaning compound;
At a hand washing facility that is equipped as specified in Regulation .18K and L of this chapter; and
By:
Vigorously rubbing together the surfaces of lathered hands and arms for at least 20 seconds;
Cleaning under the nails with a brush if needed; and
Thoroughly rinsing the hands and arms with clean water;
An employee keeps hands clean while engaged in handling food and food-contact surfaces;
An employee who handles exposed food and food-contact surfaces:
Keeps fingernails clean and neatly trimmed;
Unless wearing gloves that are in good repair, does not wear fingernail polish or artificial fingernails;
Except for a plain, smooth ring such as a wedding band, does not wear jewelry;
Wears outer garments that are clean;
Uses hairnets, caps, or other effective hair restraints in order to keep hair from contacting food and food-contact surfaces;
Maintains personal cleanliness; and
Except as provided in §L of this regulation, does not eat, drink, or use tobacco in any form while working;
An employee does not use bare hands for handling ready-to-eat foods, as set forth in Regulation .09E of this chapter;
An employee using gloves to protect exposed food:
Uses gloves only for one task;
Does not use the same gloves while working with ready-to-eat food and raw food; and
Discards used gloves when:
The gloves are damaged or soiled;
An interruption occurs in the operation; or
After 2 hours of continuous use;
An employee receives training in proper food handling and sanitation as it relates to assigned duties; and
When in a food preparation or utensil washing area, an employee:
Drinks only from a covered beverage container; and
Handles the container in a way that prevents contamination of:
The employee's hands;
Exposed food;
Clean equipment;
Utensils;
Linens; and
Unwrapped single service and single use articles.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Except as provided in §§A(2) and (14) and B of this regulation, food equipment meets one or more of the following design standards:
National Sanitation Foundation (NSF) or equivalent sanitation certification from:
The Etlsemko division of Intertek Group PLC (Intertek ETL SEMKO);
Canadian Standards Association (CSA); or
Underwriters Laboratories (UL);
Baking Industry Sanitation Standards Committee;
National Automation Merchandizing Association;
International Association of Milk and Food Sanitarian's "3-A Sanitary Standards"; or
Another applicable published standard acceptable to the approving authority;
When design standards conflict with State laws, codes, or regulations, the State laws, codes, or regulations are followed;
Equipment and utensils are designed, constructed, and maintained to:
Accomplish the intended and required functions;
Protect food from internal and external contamination;
Be durable under normal conditions and operations;
Be resistant to:
Denting;
Buckling;
Pitting;
Chipping;
Crazing; and
Excessive wear;
Have non-food contact surfaces where exposed to splash, food debris, or other soils that are:
Smooth;
Washable; and
Readily accessible;
Withstand repeated scrubbing, scouring, corrosive action of food, cleansers, and sanitizing agents; and
Prevent harboring of soils, bacteria, or pests:
In or on the equipment; and
Between the equipment and other equipment, floors, walls, or supports;
Materials used as food contact surfaces of equipment are:
Nontoxic;
Unable to contaminate or be absorbed by food under the conditions of use;
Non-porous and nonabsorbent; and
Except for the use of cast iron as a food contact material if the surface is to be heated, corrosion resistant;
Food contact surfaces of equipment and utensils are designed, constructed, and maintained to be:
Smooth;
Easily cleanable;
In good repair;
Free of difficult to clean internal corners and crevices;
Self-emptying or self-draining if an interior surface;
Visible or readily disassembled for inspection; and
Readily:
Accessible for manual cleaning without tools; or
Disassembled with the use of simple tools kept available near the equipment;
Equipment designed for pressurized cleaning-in-place is designed, constructed, and maintained to:
Fully circulate cleaning and sanitizing solutions through a fixed system in which the solutions will contact all interior food contact surfaces;
Self-drain or otherwise completely evacuate all cleaning solutions; and
Effectively clean and sanitize all food contact surfaces without disassembly;
Cutting blocks, bakers tables, and similar wood food contact surfaces are made from:
Hard maple; or
Another material that is:
Nontoxic;
Smooth; and
Free of cracks, crevices, and open seams;
Lubricants used on bearings and gears of equipment are food-grade;
Except for equipment that is portable, equipment that is placed on tables or counters is:
Sealed in place;
Mounted on legs or feet at least 4 inches high; or
Installed to allow cleaning of the equipment and adjacent areas;
Floor-mounted equipment is:
Elevated:
At least 6 inches above the floor; and
So that food contact surfaces are at least 18 inches above the floor; and
Placed so that there is sufficient space for cleaning between:
Adjoining units; and
A unit and the adjacent walls;
The spaces between adjoining equipment are closed and sealed if exposed to seepage;
Aisles or working spaces between equipment and between equipment and walls are:
Unobstructed and of sufficient width to permit employees to perform duties without contaminating food or food-contact surfaces by clothing or personal contact; and
In a new facility or a facility that is remodeled, a minimum width of:
3 feet where food preparation occurs on only one side of the aisle;
4 feet where food preparation occurs on both sides of the aisle and employees work back to back;
5 feet where food preparation occurs on both sides of the aisle, employees work back to back, and other employees must pass through the area; or
Another width approved by the approving authority based on a review that indicates compliance with §A(12)(a) of this regulation;
Equipment is installed and located to limit the potential for cross-contamination of food;
When an existing piece of equipment ceases to operate:
Equipment intended for temporary use is:
Acceptable to the approving authority; and
In compliance with §A(3)—(8) of this regulation;
Equipment is replaced:
With equipment that meets the requirements of this regulation; and
Within 30 working days from the date the permanent replacement plan required in §A(14)(c) of this regulation is accepted by the approving authority; and
The approving authority is provided plans for permanent replacement of the failed unit within 10 working days after the failure of the unit; and
A vending machine containing potentially hazardous foods has an automatic control that prevents the machine from vending food:

If there is a power failure, mechanical failure, or other condition resulting in an internal machine temperature that cannot maintain food temperatures as specified in Regulation .06B(7) of this chapter; and
Until serviced and working properly.
The approving authority may allow the use of equipment that meets §A(3)—(10) of this regulation but fails to comply with §A(1) of this regulation if a review indicates the equipment and its use are:
Not harmful to public health; and
Consistent with industry standards and practice.

section.heading: Cleaning and Sanitizing Equipment and Utensils.

para.text: Food contact surfaces of equipment and utensils are effectively cleaned and sanitized by:
Removing soil and food particles by one or more of the following:
Flushing;
Soaking;
Scraping;
Cleaning with a suitable commercial detergent;
Rinsing with potable water; and
Sanitizing, using:
Immersion in hot water of 170°F or higher temperature for at least 30 seconds;
Immersion in a chemical sanitizer that is proven to kill pathogens effectively:
In accordance with the manufacturer's label use instructions; or
As set forth in §C(1) of this regulation; or
For equipment that is not sanitized by the methods set forth in §C(1) of this regulation:
Live steam from a hose, provided that the steam can be confined within the equipment;
A rinse with boiling water; or
A spray or swab with a chemical sanitizing solution of at least the minimum strength stated in §C(1) of this regulation;
Cleaning and sanitization occur:
As often as needed to prevent food contamination;
After each use;
Between an interruption in food preparation greater than 4 hours; and
Except for food contact surfaces of equipment or utensils within holding units that are maintained at proper temperatures, after a continuous use of 4 hours;
When sanitizer is used for the manual sanitization of food contact surfaces of equipment and utensils:
The minimum level of sanitizer provided is:
50 parts per million chlorine with a minimum water temperature of 75°F and a minimum contact time of 7 seconds;
12.5—25 parts per million iodine with a minimum water temperature of 75°F and a minimum contact time of 30 seconds; or
The concentration indicated on the manufacturer's label with a minimum contact time of 30 seconds for quaternary ammonium compound; and
A test kit or other device that accurately measures concentration of the sanitizer in parts per million is provided and used to check that the minimum level of sanitizer is accurate;
When hot water is used as the sanitizing agent in manual operations, a graduated thermometer is provided that is:
Accurate within plus or minus 2°F;
Calibrated annually or more frequently;
Located near the sink; and
Used frequently to check water temperature;
A three-compartment sink is:
Provided and used wherever warewashing is conducted manually;
Adequate in length, width, and depth to accommodate the largest equipment items and utensils;
Supplied with hot and cold running water at each sink compartment; and
If used for tasks other than warewashing, such as washing wiping cloths or produce or thawing food:
Is washed and sanitized before and after the sink is used for a different task; and
Does not contain an automatic chemical dispenser;
Dish tables or integral drainboards are:
Of adequate size for proper handling of soiled utensils before washing and for cleaned utensils following rinsing or sanitization;
Located and constructed so the tables or drainboards do not interfere with the proper use of the warewashing facilities; and
Not required for cooks' and bakers' rinse sinks;
When spray-type warewashing machines are used:
The machines are installed:
According to manufacturer's specifications; and
To provide effective cleaning and sanitization of equipment and utensils;
The manufacturer's specifications are listed on a data plate that is permanently affixed to the machine;
If manufacturer's specifications for wash and rinse water temperature do not exist, the following standards are followed:
For machines using chemical sanitization, the wash and final rinse water temperature is at least 120°F; or
For machines using hot water sanitization, the wash water is at least:
160°F for single tank conveyor machines; and
150°F for other types of machines;
For machines using hot water sanitization, the final or fresh rinse water temperature is at least:
180°F at the entrance of the manifold; or
160°F when a pumped rinse is provided;
Wash water is kept clean and rinse water tanks are protected by:
Distance;
Baffles; or
Other means to minimize the entry of wash water into the rinse water;
The flow pressure is not less than 15 or more than 25 pounds per square inch on the water line immediately adjacent to the final rinse control valve;
Except for a pumped or recirculated final rinse, a pressure gauge is provided immediately upstream from the final rinse control valve to check the flow pressure of the final rinse water; and
An easily readable thermometer is provided to measure water temperature with an accuracy of plus or minus 2°F:
In each tank of the warewashing machine; and
As the final rinse water enters the manifold;
Jets, nozzles, and all other parts of each machine are maintained free of:
Chemical deposits;
Debris; and
Other soil; and
If used, automatic detergent dispensers are maintained and operating;
All warewashing machines are thoroughly cleaned as often as needed throughout the day to:
Prevent recontamination of equipment and utensils; and
Ensure that the equipment performs the equipment's intended function;
A pre-rinse device is provided for all warewashing machines;
Equipment and utensils are placed in racks, trays, baskets, or on conveyors after flushing, scraping, or soaking so that food contact surfaces are:
Subject to unobstructed application of detergent wash;
Rinsed thoroughly with clean rinse water to remove particulate matter and detergent residues; and
Drained;
Warewashing machines using chemicals for sanitization meet the following additional requirements:
Chemicals added for sanitization purposes are automatically dispensed; and
The chemical sanitizer used:
Is listed in 21 CFR §178.1010; and
Provides the equivalent bactericidal effect of a solution containing at least 50 parts per million of chlorine; and
A test kit or other device that accurately measures the concentration of the sanitizing solution is used;

Written approval is obtained from the approving authority when any other type of machine, device, or facilities and procedures for warewashing will be used based on a review that indicates compliance with §A of this regulation;
Non-food contact surfaces of equipment are cleaned frequently enough to preclude the accumulation of soil residues; and
Wiping cloths are:
Used only for wiping food spills;
Free of food debris when used dry for wiping food spills on tableware; and
Rinsed and stored in one of the sanitizing solutions specified in §C(1) of this regulation when used wet for wiping spills from the surfaces of equipment.

section.heading: Storage and Handling of Cleaned Equipment and Utensils.

para.text: Contamination of food-contact surfaces of cleaned and sanitized equipment and utensils is prevented by handling:
Cleaned spoons, knives, and forks by the utensil's handles only; and
Cleaned cups, glasses, and bowls so that hands do not contact inside surfaces or mouth-contact surfaces;
The food-contact surfaces of equipment are protected from:
Splash;
Dust; and
Other contamination;
Cleaned and sanitized food equipment, portable equipment, and utensils are stored:
A minimum of 18 inches above the floor when not fully protected by an enclosure with doors;
In a clean, dry location; and
In a space that affords protection from splash, dust, and other contamination;
Utensils are:
Air dried before being stored; or
Stored in a self-draining position on hooks or racks constructed of a corrosion resistant material;
Stored containers and utensils are covered or inverted whenever possible;
Flatware is stored in containers designed to present the handle to the employee or customer;
Toilet rooms or vestibules are not used to store:
Food equipment;
Utensils; or
Single service articles; and
Single service articles are:
Stored in closed cartons or containers to protect the articles from contamination;
Handled and dispensed in a manner that prevents contamination of surfaces that come into contact with food or the mouth of the user; and
Used only once.
Potable water is:
Obtained from a water supply system that complies with Environment Article, Title 9, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 26.04.04; and
Meets the standards of quality specified in Environment Article, Title 9, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 26.04.01;
Non-potable water for non-culinary purposes such as air conditioning or fire protection is used only if the system complies with §H(3) of this regulation;
Except for a temporary food service facility where water under pressure is not available, hot and cold running water under pressure is provided:
In all areas where:
Food is prepared; and
Equipment and utensils are washed; and
With sufficient water capacity, pressure, and hot water generation and distribution to meet peak demands throughout the facility;
Drinking water, if not dispensed through the water supply system of the food service facility, is potable and stored in a container that meets all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations;
Steam that contacts food is free from deleterious or harmful matter that might adulterate food;
All water-carried sewage is disposed of by:
A public sewerage system; or
An approved sewage disposal system constructed and operated in conformance with applicable State and local laws, ordinances, and regulations;
Where water-carried disposal methods are not possible, non-water-carried sewage disposal facilities are utilized if:
The method has been approved by the approving authority as meeting State and local requirements; and
The facilities are:
In conformance with applicable State and local laws, ordinances, and regulations; and
Located outside and not attached to the establishment;
Plumbing is sized, installed, and maintained so that:
The plumbing complies with applicable State and local plumbing laws, ordinances, and regulations;
The potable water supply system is:
Installed in a manner that prevents backflow or backsiphonage; and
Not connected with a non-potable water system in a manner that would allow non-potable water to be drawn or discharged into the potable water supply system;
The piping of a non-potable water system is:
Marked so that the piping is readily distinguishable from piping that carries potable water, such as with distinctive yellow-colored paint; and
Not connected to equipment or other outlets in the food preparation area;
Indirect waste piping is provided to a:
Food preparation or utensil washing sink;
Refrigerator coil;
Ice making machine;
Steam kettle;
Coffee urn or brewer;
Hot or cold drink machine;
Steam table;
Potato peeler;
Warewashing machine, unless:
The machine is located within 5 feet of a trapped floor drain; and
The waste piping is connected directly to the inlet side of a floor drain trap vented in conformance with applicable State and local laws, ordinances, and regulations; and
Similar piece of equipment in which food, portable equipment, or utensils are placed;

Each compartment of a multiple compartment sink is indirectly drained to a trapped and vented plumbing receptor through an air gap that complies with State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances:
From a separate pipe through the air gap and into the plumbing receptor; or
Through the air gap into a single manifolded branch and into the plumbing receptor;
Plumbing receptors receiving the discharge of indirect waste pipes:
Have a shape and capacity that will prevent splashing or flooding; and
Are accessible for cleaning and inspection;
Food waste grinders are connected and trapped separately from other fixtures or sink compartments;
Floor drains subject to evaporation have:
A water seal of at least 4 inches;
Water fed from a plumbing fixture that complies with State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances; or
An automatic priming device that complies with State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances;
Floor drains in storerooms, refrigerated rooms, walk-in coolers, or other locations where food is stored, have indirect waste piping;
Hand sinks in food preparation tables and counters discharge through an air gap into a floor sink or receptor that is trapped and vented; and
Except when required by building design, waste pipes and fixtures are:
Not located over food storage, preparation, or serving areas; and
Where installed over food storage, preparation, or serving areas, food is protected by one or more of the following:
Pipe joining methods that will preclude leakage;
Using wall-mounted fixtures;
Limiting the number of pipe joints;
Pressure testing the piping;
Thermally insulating pipes to prevent condensation; and
Installing integral seepage pans or pipe sleeves;
Toilet facilities are:
Sufficient in number to serve the facility;
