Conveniently located;
Accessible to employees at all times;
Except as specified in Health-General Article, §21-325(b), Annotated Code of Maryland, for facilities established after January 1, 1979, provided for patrons whenever a food service facility:
Prepares food and provides seating; or
Is a carry-out facility with indoor tables used for dining;
Installed in accordance with applicable State and local laws, ordinances, and regulations;
Designed with fixtures that are:
Of sanitary design; and
Readily cleanable;
Kept:
Clean;
In good repair; and
Free of objectionable odor; and
Supplied with:
Toilet tissue at each toilet at all times; and
Receptacles that are easily cleanable and covered for waste materials in toilet rooms for women;
Toilet rooms:
Are completely enclosed;
Are equipped with self-closing doors except when a toilet room without doors is approved by the approving authority based on a review that shows that:
Doors would impede the use of the toilet room; and
The requirements in §J(3)—(6) of this regulation are met;
Provide privacy;
Are provided mechanical ventilation that:
Exhausts air at the rate of 2 cubic feet per minute per square foot of floor area; and
Allows the entrance of an equal amount of makeup air;
Prevent the entry of insects and vermin; and
Do not open directly into the kitchen or food preparation areas;
Hand washing facilities are:
Located:
In each food preparation and processing area;
In each utensil washing area; and
Adjacent to all toilet rooms;
Accessible at all times;
Equipped with an adequate supply of hand-cleaning soap or detergent;
Equipped with a means of drying hands, such as:
Individual towels in dispensers; or
An effective hand-drying device;
Equipped with a waste receptacle; and
Kept clean and in good repair;
Hand sinks are:
Installed in accordance with applicable State and local laws, ordinances, and regulations;
Able to discharge:
Hot and cold running water; or
Tempered running water at a temperature of at least 100°F through:
A mixing valve;
A combination faucet; or
Any slow closing or metering faucet that provides a flow of water for at least 15 seconds before the faucet has to be reactivated; and
Utensil washing vats, food preparation sinks, or mop sinks are not used as hand sinks.
Garbage is stored in the following ways as applicable to the facility:
In containers that:
Are sufficient in number to hold all of the garbage that accumulates between periods of removal from the premises;
Do not leak or absorb liquids;
Are constructed of durable metal or another approved type of material; and
Are provided with tight-fitting lids or covers unless kept in a:
Vermin-proofed room or enclosure; or
Waste refrigerator;
In storage areas that:
Are clean; and
Do not constitute a nuisance;
In storage rooms or enclosures that:
Are constructed of easily cleanable, grease resistant, washable materials; and
Are vermin-proofed;
In garbage containers outside the establishment that are located on a grease resistant, durable surface; and
For damaged, adulterated, or recalled products, in designated areas separate from:
Food;
Equipment;
Utensils;
Linens; and
Single service and single use articles that are held for credit, redemption, or return to the distributor;
Garbage containers are cleaned as necessary to prevent a buildup of soil:
In a manner that does not contaminate food, equipment, utensils, or food preparation areas;
With:
Brushes for washing that may not be used for any other purpose;
Can-washing machines;
Steam-cleaning devices; or
Similar equipment; and
In an area that enables waste water from cleaning operations to be disposed of as sewage;
Food waste grinders are:
Constructed and installed to comply with applicable State and local plumbing laws, ordinances, and regulations; and
Not connected to a sink drain that is used for food or utensils;
All garbage and rubbish is disposed of:
Daily, or as often as necessary, to prevent a nuisance or insanitary condition; and
By a method that complies with applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances; and
Used cooking grease and oils are stored, recycled, and disposed of in accordance with applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances.
A food service facility may operate with its outer doors and windows open unless, while the food service facility is operating with the outer doors or outer windows open, the approving authority:
Finds evidence of vermin in food preparation or food storage areas; or
Finds evidence of flying insects in food preparation or food storage areas that pose a significant threat to sanitation or public health.

If the approving authority finds that a food service facility is operating in violation of §A of this regulation, the food service facility shall take immediate action to eliminate the vermin or flying insects.
If the approving authority finds that a food service facility is operating in violation of §A of this regulation, the approving authority may:
Close a food service facility;
Order a temporary closure of the outer windows and outer doors, until the vermin or flying insects are eliminated from the food preparation or food storage areas; or
Take another action to eliminate vermin or flying insects.
A food service facility found to be operating in violation of §A of this regulation on three or more separate occasions shall keep the outer windows and outer doors closed at all times until:
Modifications approved by the local approving authority are made to the food service facility to effectively protect against the entrance of vermin and flying insects; or
Another action acceptable by the approval authority is taken.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Effective control measures are used to eliminate rodents, flies, roaches, and other vermin from the building;
The premises are kept clean and free of debris that will promote the harborage of vermin;
Openings into the building are effectively protected against the entrance of insects and rodents by:
Doors that are:
Tight; and
Self-closing;
Screening on windows, doors, skylights, transoms, and other openings, which is:
Tight-fitting;
In good repair; and
Made of material that is not less than 16-mesh to the inch or equivalent;
Positive air pressure or controlled air currents; and
Other means acceptable to the approving authority; and
Insect control devices that are used to electrocute or stun flying insects are:
Designed to retain the insects within the device;
Not located over areas used to prepare food; and
Located so that dead insects and insect fragments are prevented from being impelled or from falling onto:
Exposed food;
Clean equipment;
Utensils;
Linens; and
Unwrapped single service and single use articles.
A floor and floor covering is kept:
Clean; and
In good repair;

The floor in a food preparation, food processing, food storage, utensil washing, dressing or locker, toilet, and walk-in refrigerator room or area is constructed of epoxy, sealed concrete, quarry tile, ceramic tile, commercial grade continuous sheet vinyl, or similar material that makes the floor:
Smooth;
Durable;
Nonabsorbent, unless the floor is in a:
Dry-food storage area;
Dining area; or
Mechanical or electrical room;
Easily cleanable; and
Grease resistant in areas subject to grease spillage or drippage;

A floor installed in a food preparation, food processing, food storage, utensil washing, walk-in refrigerator, dressing or locker, and toilet room or area has a juncture between the floor and the wall that is:
Coved; and
Closed;
A mat, floor covering, and duckboard is:
Removable;
Easily cleanable; and
Kept clean;
When carpeting is used, the carpeting is placed only on the floors of:
Interior dining areas;
Retail areas where liquid products are not displayed; and
Areas not subject to water flushing, spraying, or drippage;
When a floor receives water as a result of processing or cleaning, floor drains are provided at a minimum of one floor drain per 400 square feet of floor area;
When floor drains are installed, floors are graded at not less than 1/8 inch per foot to direct wastewater to the floor drains;
A floor in a room without floor drains that requires the removal of processing or wash-water, is drained by:
Sloping the floor at least 1/8 inch per foot toward a doorway or another opening; and
Directing the wastewater into a floor drain or other discharge point located outside the room in compliance with applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances;
The walking and driving surfaces of all exterior areas of food service facilities are:
Kept clean and free of debris; and
Surfaced with concrete, asphalt, gravel, or similar material to facilitate maintenance and minimize dusty or muddy conditions;
A door on the building's exterior is equipped with a self-closing device;
A wall, ceiling, door, window, skylight, and similar closure, is kept:
Clean; and
In good repair;
The walls up to at least the highest level reached by splash or spray in all food preparation, food storage, utensil washing, and toilet rooms or areas have surfaces that are:
Smooth;
Washable; and
Water and grease resistant;
A wall covering material, such as tile, stainless steel, fiber reinforced plastic, sealed gypsum board, or a similar material, is attached and sealed to the wall or ceiling so that:
There are no open spaces or cracks to permit accumulation of grease or soil;
The surface is easily cleanable; and
Harborage for vermin is prevented;
Ceiling covering materials in food preparation and utensil washing areas:
Have smooth, washable surfaces; and
Do not contain fiberglass backing;
Exposed construction, such as exposed floor and ceiling rafters, trusses or beams, utility ducts, and lighting, is:
Used only in:
A dry food storage area;
A dining area; or
Other areas with the approval of the approving authority based on applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances;
Not used in:
A refrigerated food storage area;
A food preparation area;
An equipment and utensil washing area; and
A toilet room; and
Cleanable; and
Piping, conduit, and similar construction located outside a wall is installed so that there is a minimum of 3/4 inch space between the piping, conduit, and similar construction and the wall.
Light fixtures, decorative material, and similar equipment and material attached to walls or ceilings are kept clean;
Lighting provides artificial light at:
50 footcandles at a surface where a food employee is working with food, utensils, or equipment;
20 footcandles at 30 inches from the floor in a:
Storage area;
Toilet room;
Locker room;
Garbage and rubbish storage area;
Dining area during cleaning;
Utensil washing area;
Bar;
Wait station; and
Service area; or
Another lighting level approved by the approving authority based on a review that indicates the lighting level is sufficient for cleaning, facility maintenance, and employee safety.
Light bulbs and tubes are shielded to prevent broken glass from falling onto food and utensils;
Infrared or other heat lamps are protected against breakage by a shield surrounding and extending beyond the bulb, leaving only the face of the bulb exposed;
The facility is ventilated with ventilation equipment that is maintained and operated so that:
All areas are kept reasonably free from:
Excessive heat;
Steam;
Condensation;
Vapors;
Smoke; and
Fumes;
Outside air is supplied:
Through:
The HVAC system;
A separate supply fan; or
A combination of the HVAC system and a separate supply fan;
So that the entry of outdoor contaminants is excluded by:
Maintaining the building under a slight positive pressure; and
Providing an air filtering system; and
So that it does not reduce the effectiveness of the exhaust system;
Mechanical exhaust and make-up air systems are connected by an interlocking switch in order to provide make-up air whenever the exhaust system is in operation; and
Make-up air is tempered when necessary to:
Prevent the build-up of condensation that could:
Result in an unsanitary condition within the facility; and
Contaminate food;
Provide comfortable working conditions; and
Comply with applicable building codes;
Rooms, areas, and equipment from which aerosols, odors, fumes, or vapors may originate are effectively vented to the outside air by a system that does not create a harmful or unlawful discharge;
A ventilation hood or other ventilation device or fixture is designed:
To prevent grease or condensate from dripping onto food or onto food preparation surfaces;
In compliance with NSF Standard 2; and
So that interior and exterior parts are easily accessible for maintenance and cleaning;
Intake air ducts are designed and maintained to prevent the entrance of:
Dust;
Dirt;
Insects; or
Other contaminating materials;
A grease removing exhaust hood is provided when needed over commercial cooking equipment that produces grease-laden vapors or smoke, such as:
Griddles;
Fryers;
Charbroilers;
Ovens used to cook fatty foods at a temperature which exceeds the vaporization point of grease; and
Solid fuel cooking equipment;
A ventilation hood is provided over equipment where needed, for heat, fumes, and steam removal, including:
High temperature ovens not cooking fatty foods or not emitting grease vapors;
Steam kettles; and
Warewashing machines using hot water sanitization;
Overshelves are used over cooking equipment under a hood only if:
Deflectors or the design of the overshelf prevents grease from condensing on the bottom of the overshelf and contaminating the food below;
Deflectors meet NSF or equivalent standards for food zone materials; and
The ability of the hood to capture grease vapors and smoke is not impaired;
Equipment is not added or substituted under a hood that exceeds the capacity of the hood to remove:
Heat;
Steam;
Smoke;
Grease;
Fumes; and
Obnoxious odors;
Except as provided in §N of this regulation, ventilation in toilet rooms is provided:
So that 2 cubic feet of air per minute per square foot of floor space is mechanically exhausted to the outside; and
With make-up air;
When an existing building is converted for use as a food service facility and there is no feasible method to vent the toilet room to the exterior of the building, a ductless exhaust fan is used that:
Is sized and installed so that it will move 2 cubic feet of air per minute per square foot of floor area; and
Is serviced and maintained according to the manufacturer's specifications; and
Required ventilation meets the provisions of this regulation:
Initially; and
For the life of the system.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
The facility and parts of the property associated with the operation of the facility are kept:
Clean; and
Free of litter and rubbish;
Traffic through the food operation and utensil washing areas is limited to on-duty personnel conducting pertinent job-related functions;
The facility is not used for living or sleeping quarters;
Sufficient space to store all custodial equipment is provided;
At least one utility sink or curbed cleaning facility with a floor drain is provided and used for:
Cleaning mops or similar wet floor cleaning tools; and
The disposal of mop water or similar liquid wastes;
A hand sink, utensil washing, equipment washing, or food preparation sink is not used as a mop or utility sink;
Except for emergency cleaning due to an accident or spill, all cleaning is done during periods when the least amount of food is exposed, such as after closing to the public;
Cleaning and sanitizing occur in a manner that protects food from contamination;
Vacuum cleaning, wet cleaning, other dustless methods of floor and wall cleaning, or dust-arresting sweeping compounds and brooms are used in a manner that:
Removes dust and soils; and
Prevents the contamination of food and food-contact surfaces;
Linens and clothes are stored:
Laundered and in a clean place until used; and
In non-absorbent containers or laundry bags when damp or soiled until removed for laundering;
Employee clothing and personal belongings are stored in:
Dressing rooms or dedicated areas that are:
Provided when employees change clothing within the facility;
Located outside of food preparation, serving, and utensil washing areas; and
Kept clean; and
Lockers or other facilities within dressing rooms or areas; and
Live birds and animals are not present on the premises of a food service facility except for:
Edible fish, shellfish, crustacea, or decorative fish in aquariums or display tank systems;
Service animals that are controlled by the individual with a disability;
Pets in the common dining areas of health care facilities at times other than during meals if:
Effective partitioning and self-closing doors separate the common dining areas from food storage and food preparation areas;
Condiments, equipment, and utensils are stored in enclosed cabinets or removed from the common dining area when pets are present; and
Dining areas including tables and countertops are cleaned and sanitized before the next meal service; and
A patron’s dog in an outdoor dining area of a food service facility in conformance with applicable State and local laws, ordinances, and regulations.
Patrons' Dogs in Outdoor Dining Areas.

Subject to the requirements of §§B(2)—(5) of this regulation, an owner of a restaurant may allow a patron's dog to accompany the patron in the outdoor dining area during the hours designated by the restaurant.
Before an owner may allow a patron's dog to accompany the patron in the outdoor dining area, the owner shall:

Provide written notice to the approving authority or the local health department in the jurisdiction where the restaurant is located that the owner intends to allow patrons' dogs to accompany patrons in the outdoor dining area of the restaurant 30 days prior to the days dogs will be allowed; and
Place on permanent display in the restaurant a written notice that:
States the restaurant's policy of allowing patrons' dogs in an outdoor dining area;
Is in a typeface that is large enough to be easily legible to the average person from a distance of 8 feet; and
Is in a location that is plainly visible to the patrons of the restaurant.
In establishing the restaurant's policy concerning patron's dogs in outdoor dining areas, the owner may:
Determine the location and the amount of space designated for a patron accompanied by the patron's dog; and
Establish a limit on the size and type of dogs and any other limitations relating to a patron's dog.
At the owner's discretion, the owner may deny entry to the restaurant or eject from the restaurant any patron and the patron's dog.
A patron accompanied by a dog:
Shall:
Be an adult who is responsible for the behavior of the dog;
Keep the dog with the patron on a leash at all times at the table at which the patron is seated; and
Be liable for any damages caused by the dog to the restaurant or any other patron of the restaurant; and
May not:
Allow the dog to travel through an indoor space of a restaurant to enter or exit an outdoor dining area; or
Leave the dog unattended at any time.

section.heading: Food Manufacturing in Food Service Facilities.

para.text: A person who is licensed to operate a food service facility may manufacture food for sale or distribution as provided in §§B, C, and E of this regulation.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that before a food is manufactured in a food service facility:
Plans for the manufacturing:
Are submitted to the Department;
Are approved in writing by the Department based on a review that indicates compliance with this regulation;
Include:
A list of foods proposed for manufacture;
The proposed processing procedures for a food;
Specifications for equipment items to be used for manufacture;
Packaging and labeling information;
Methods of shipment;
Procedures for maintaining potentially hazardous food as set forth in Regulation .06B(7)—(13) of this chapter; and
An HACCP plan in accordance with Regulation .34 of this chapter; and
The facilities and equipment proposed for use in manufacturing are:
Inspected by the Department; and
Approved in writing by the Department based on a review that indicates compliance with this chapter.
A person licensed only to operate a food service facility may not manufacture the following foods:
Low-acid canned foods as defined in 21 CFR §113.3(n);
Acidified foods as defined in 21 CFR §114.3(b);
Hermetically sealed and ready-to-eat potentially hazardous foods that a hazard analysis indicates are associated with the outgrowth of Clostridium botulinum or Listeria monocytogenes, such as:
Smoked fish; or
Pasteurized crabmeat;
Bottled water; or
Soft drinks.
The approving authority shall routinely inspect the food manufacturing conducted in the food service facility:
During inspections of the retail food service facility; and
At a frequency set forth in Regulation .30 of this chapter.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
All manufactured food is labeled in accordance with Regulation .12 of this chapter; and
Records are:
Made to allow the trace-back of distributed or sold food to the food service facility that manufactured the food;
Made to identify the immediate source of the food and food ingredients stored and processed at the facility;
For shell eggs, made to provide the information required in COMAR 15.04.01.03A(2)(a)—(e);
Made to identify the initial distribution of the food to facilitate the segregation of food that may have become adulterated or otherwise unfit for human consumption; and
Maintained at the facility for at least:
2 years for a shelf stable or preserved food; and
1 year for a fresh food.

For a special food service facility that handles only potentially hazardous food that remains in the original container or wrapping and that does not prepare, wrap, or package the food at the facility, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance is maintained with Regulations .01—.06, .08, .12—.14, .15A(3)—(5), .19—.23, .25, .28—.33, and .35—.39 of this chapter; and
When single service articles are used, the single service articles comply with Regulation .17H of this chapter.
For a special food service facility that handles food that is removed from the original package or that prepares, packages, or wraps food at the facility, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance is maintained with Regulations .01—.06, .08—.14, .15A(3)—(10), .16—.25, and .28—.39 of this chapter;
The premises are kept clean and free of litter or rubbish;
If permanent toilet facilities are not required, temporary toilet facilities are made available and maintained in a sanitary manner;
Except as provided in §D(2) of this regulation, adequate hand washing facilities are provided by:
Where potable water under pressure is available, a hand sink as set forth in Regulation .18K and L of this chapter; or
Another hand washing facility that has:
Warm water;
Soap; and
Paper towels; and
Wastewater from hand washing, food preparation, and cleaning is disposed of in accordance with State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances.
For a special food service facility that is a mobile unit, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance is maintained with either §A or B of this regulation as applicable;
Equipment components of the mobile unit are in compliance with Regulation .15A(1) and (2) or B of this chapter;
A hand washing sink is provided as set forth in Regulation .18K and L of this chapter;
Potable water tanks are used to provide water for hand washing and, where applicable, for food preparation and utensil cleaning;
Wastewater tanks are used to hold wastewater pending disposal at a facility in a manner that conforms with State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances;
Subject to §C(8) and (9) of this regulation, a base of operations is established that provides:
A source of potable water, potable water hoses, and clean connections;
A method for the disposal of sewage;
Clean, adequate, and covered trash receptacles;
A storage area for single serve food items; and
If necessary:
Refrigerated and dry food storage areas; and
A utensil washing facility.
The base of operation is located within 90 miles of the licensing county;
For a mobile food service facility not seeking a mobile reciprocity license, a base of operations as set forth in §C(6) and (7) of this regulation is established by May 1, 2020;
A base of operations is not required for a mobile food service facility that offers only prepackaged frozen desserts;
A valid license from the county of origin is maintained; and
Compliance is maintained with all applicable State and local laws and regulations in the jurisdiction in which it is operating.
For a special food service facility that is a temporary food service facility, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance is maintained with either §A or B of this regulation as applicable, except that no compliance with Regulations .21 and .22 of this chapter is required;
Where potable water under pressure is not available, sufficient containerized potable water is provided for:
Hand washing; and
Rinsing utensils; and
The period of time that the facility operates is limited to the time stated in Regulation .02B(80) of this chapter.
For a special food service that is a bed and breakfast, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance is maintained with either §A or B of this regulation as applicable;
The facility serves hot meals only to renters; and
The facility does not operate as a restaurant or caterer.
For a special food service facility that is a semi-permanent food service facility, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance is maintained with either §A or B of this chapter as applicable;
A connection to potable water is maintained as a critical item, as set forth in Regulation .18A of this chapter;
Hand sinks are provided and maintained as set forth in Regulation .18K and L of this chapter; and
A connection to a sewage disposal system is provided and maintained as a critical item that meets applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances.
For a special food service facility that is an on-farm food service facility, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance is maintained with either §A or B of this regulation as applicable, except that no compliance with Regulations .21 and .22 of this chapter is required;
Hand washing stations are provided in close proximity to the food service facility for use by customers;
Signs are displayed prominently at the hand washing stations stating "In the interests of public health, please wash your hands thoroughly before entering or handling food."; and
The period of time that the facility operates is limited to the time in Regulation .02B(48) of this chapter.
For a special food service facility that is a seasonal farmer’s market producer sampling food service facility, the person-in-charge shall ensure that:

Compliance is maintained with §B of this regulation when food is removed from the original package or food is prepared at the facility, except that no compliance with Regulations .21 and .22 of this chapter is required;
Where potable water under pressure is not available, sufficient containerized potable water is provided for:
Hand washing; and
Rinsing utensils; and
The period of time that the facility operates is limited to the time stated in Regulation .02B(70) of this chapter.

Pursuant to Health-General Article, §21-304(a)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland, a volunteer fire company or bona fide nonprofit fraternal, civic, war veterans’, religious, or charitable organization or corporation that does not serve food to the public more often than 4 days per week, except that once a year an organization may serve food to the public for up to 30 consecutive days, may make:
A rescindable decision to operate as a licensed food service facility and in full compliance with this chapter; or

A decision to operate without a license and in compliance with §§B—E of this regulation, which establish the minimum requirements to ensure food safety at a food preparation or serving area operated by an excluded organization without a license.

The person-in-charge shall ensure that a food preparation or service area operated by an excluded organization without a license complies with Regulations .01—.15A(3)—(10), .16—.23, .26—.27, and .29—.39 of this chapter.
During the operation of a special food service facility, the person-in-charge of an unlicensed excluded organization shall ensure compliance with:
Regulations .01—.06, .08, .12—.14, .15A(3)—(5), .19—.20, .22B—D, .23, .26, .29—.33, and .35—.39 of this chapter, if the unlicensed excluded organization is a special food service facility that:
Handles only potentially hazardous food that remains within the original container or wrapping; and
Does not prepare, wrap, or package food at the facility; or
Regulations .01—.06, .08—.14, .15A(3)—(10), .16—.20, .22B—D, .23, .26, and .29—.39 of this chapter, if the unlicensed excluded organization is a special food service facility that:
Handles food that is removed from the original container or wrapping; or
Prepares, packs, or wraps potentially hazardous food at the facility.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that an unlicensed excluded organization does not:
Operate a bed and breakfast;
Operate a semi-permanent food service; or
Except as provided for in §G of this regulation, perform retail food manufacturing.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that, when an unlicensed excluded organization plans a single event to prepare or serve potentially hazardous food to 200 or more individuals from the public:
Written notification of the event is submitted to the approving authority not less than 30 days before the scheduled event; and
The written notification required in §E(1) of this regulation contains:
The date, place, and time of the event;
The estimated number of individuals to be served at the event;
A menu or list of foods to be served;
The source of all potentially hazardous foods to be served;
A list of foods to be prepared more than 12 hours in advance of service;
If food is to be prepared off-premises, the:
Name of the facility to be used; and
Procedures for transporting food to the premises;
The name, address, and telephone number of a responsible contact individual; and
Any other information requested by the approving authority in order to review the food preparation and service.

The person-in-charge shall ensure that when an unlicensed excluded organization plans to serve food to the public for up to 30 consecutive days, a written notice is provided to the Department that includes the:
Dates on which the food will be prepared;
Methods of storing and serving food; and
Methods or procedures that will be followed to ensure food:
Safety; and
Security.

In Carroll County, a religious organization that meets the definition of an excluded organization as set forth in Regulation .02B(28) of this chapter, and complies with COMAR 10.15.01.09A—D and .10A and 10.15.04.08, or a county-owned and county-operated park or facility that is hosting a public festival, may offer for sale directly to the public the following types of homemade style food, only if the food is produced at the kitchen of the excluded organization:
Fruit butter made only from:
Apples;
Apricots;
Grapes;
Peaches;
Plums; or
Quince;
Jam, preserve, or jelly, made only from:
A fruit listed in §G(1) of this regulation;
Oranges;
Nectarines;
Tangerines;
Blackberries;
Raspberries;
Blueberries;
Boysenberries;
Cherries;
Cranberries;
Strawberries; or
Red currants;
Fruit pies made from a fruit listed in §G(1) and (2) of this regulation; and
Honey.

section.heading: Farmer's Market, Bake Sales, and Cottage Food Business.

para.text: A cottage food business may offer for sale the homemade foods specified in §B of this regulation when the foods are:
Made in a private home kitchen; and
Offered or sold only in the State:
Subject to the requirements of §C(6) and (7) of this regulation, at a retail food store; or
Directly to a consumer:
At a farmer’s market;
At a bake sale;
At a public event;
By personal delivery; or
By mail order.
The Department shall allow the preparation and sale of the following foods in accordance with §A of this regulation:
Non-potentially hazardous hot-filled canned acid fruit jellies, jams, preserves, and butters that are:
Unadulterated;
Packaged to maintain food safety and integrity; and
Labeled in accordance with Regulation .12 of this chapter;
Fruit butters made only from:
Apples;
Apricots;
Grapes;
Peaches;
Plums;
Prunes;
Quince; or
Another fruit or fruit mixture that will produce an acid canned food;
Jam, preserve, or jelly made only from:
A fruit listed in §B(2) of this regulation;
Oranges;
Nectarines;
Tangerines;
Blackberries;
Raspberries;
Blueberries;
Boysenberries;
Cherries;
Cranberries;
Strawberries;
Red currants; or
Another fruit or fruit mixture that will produce an acid canned food;
Non-potentially hazardous baked goods;
Foods manufactured on a farm by a licensed food processor in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04.19;
Non-potentially hazardous candy; and
All other non-potentially hazardous foods produced by a licensed entity.
Cottage Food Business.
The Department shall allow the owner of a cottage food business to sell only cottage food products processed and packaged in Maryland that are:
Produced or packaged in a residential kitchen;
Stored on the premises of the cottage food business; and
Prepackaged with a label that contains the following information:
The name and address of the cottage food business or the name, phone number, and identification number assigned to the cottage food business by the Department;
The name of the cottage food product;
The ingredients of the cottage food product in descending order of the amount of each ingredient by weight;
The net weight or net volume of the cottage food product;
Allergen information as specified by federal labeling requirements;
Nutritional information as specified by federal labeling requirements, if any nutritional information claim is made;

Printed in 10 point or larger type in a color that provides a clear contrast to the background of the label: “Made by a cottage food business that is not subject to Maryland’s food safety regulations.”; and
For a cottage food product offered for sale at a retail food store, the phone number and email address of the cottage food business and the date the cottage food product was made.

A cottage food business may request a unique identification number from the Department which can be used in lieu of the address of the cottage food business on the product label required under §C(1) of this regulation.
The owner of a cottage food business shall comply with all applicable county and municipal laws and ordinances regulating the preparation, processing, storage, and sale of cottage food products.
Upon receipt of a complaint or outbreak of illness the Department may:
Investigate the conditions under which the product was produced and any complaint alleging that a cottage food business has violated this regulation;
Send a representative of the Department, at a reasonable time, to enter and inspect the premises of a cottage food business to determine compliance with this regulation; and
Collect samples of a cottage food product or its ingredients to determine if the cottage food product is misbranded or adulterated.
The owner of a cottage food business may not:
Refuse to grant access to a representative who requests to enter and inspect the premises of the cottage food business in response to a complaint; or
Interfere with any inspection or collection of samples in response to a complaint or outbreak of illness.
Before the owner of a cottage food business may sell a cottage food product to a retail food store, the owner shall submit to the Department for review:
The label that will be affixed to the cottage food product in accordance with §C(1)(c) of this regulation; and

Documentation of the owner’s successful completion of a food safety course in the past 3 years that is approved by the Department and the American National Standards Institute and includes, at a minimum, the following subjects:
Basic food safety;
Cleaning and sanitizing;
Personal hygiene;
Pest control and prevention; and
Receiving, storing, preparing, and serving food.

The owner of a cottage food business may not sell or offer for sale a cottage food product to a retail food store until notified by the Department, in writing, that the requirements stated in §C(6) of this regulation are satisfactorily met.
The phone number required in §§C(1)(c)(i) and (viii) of this regulation shall enable contact with the cottage food business by the Department within 24 hours.
The email address required in §C(1)(c)(i) of this regulation shall enable contact with the cottage food business by the Department within 48 hours.
If the Department finds a person to be in violation of any provision of this regulation, the Department:

Shall take action against a misbranded or adulterated food offered or sold under this regulation in accordance with Health-General Article, §§21-211, 21-253, and 21-254, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
May determine that food produced in a private home kitchen by the person may not be offered for sale as a cottage food.

The approving authority shall require a farmer to obtain a producer mobile farmer's market unit license as specified in COMAR 10.01.17 and 10.15.04 for the sale of a farm product at a farmer's market or at a public event that is not:
A raw agricultural product as defined in Regulation .02B(61) of this chapter; or
A pre-packaged non-potentially hazardous food.
A local health department may:
Not require a farmer to obtain a producer mobile farmer's market unit license for that local jurisdiction; and

Require a farmer to obtain a seasonal farmer's market producer sampling license if the farmer prepares and offers samples of a farm product for human consumption at a farmer's market or at a public event in that local jurisdiction.
The approving authority shall issue and renew licenses in accordance with Health-General Article, §§21-309 and 21-310, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter.
The approving authority may deny an application for a food service facility license in accordance with Health-General Article, §21-311, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter.
A person:
Shall obtain a food service facility license before the person operates a food service facility; and
May not operate a food service facility if the person does not have a current and valid license issued by the approving authority, except:
As provided in:
Health-General Article, §21-305, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Regulation .26A(2) of this chapter; or
A caterer:
As provided in §G of this regulation; or

When from outside the State, that conforms to the provisions of this chapter or to substantially equivalent provisions as indicated by a report from the caterer's licensing agency to the approving authority indicating that the facility is licensed and inspected in the jurisdiction where the food service facility is located.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Application for a food service facility license is submitted in accordance with Health-General Article, §§21-306 and 21-307, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A valid license is displayed in a conspicuous place in the food service facility; and
When catering services are offered, the food service facility license number and the identity of the issuer of the number are located:
On advertising and business cards;
In published print media;
On flyers;
In brochures;
On vehicles used in connection with catering services;
On contracts for catering services;
In telephone directories; and
In or on any other advertising and solicitations.
The approving authority may not require a caterer licensed in Maryland to obtain a separate license for each catered event, including events across jurisdictional lines within the State, when the:
Major food preparation for the event is completed at the caterer's food service facility, including:
Thawing potentially hazardous food;
Cooking potentially hazardous food, except at outdoor barbecues when the food will be immediately consumed or discarded;
Cooling potentially hazardous food; or
Preparing salads that contain potentially hazardous foods; and
Event is at a location other than the caterer’s food service facility if the caterer and location comply with Regulations .01—.06, .08—.14, .15A(3)—(8), and .18I and L of this chapter.
Except as provided in §I of this regulation, a license may not be transferred from one person to another person or from one food service facility to another.
Upon the death of a licensee, the approving authority may transfer a food service facility license if:
An application is filed in accordance with Health-General Article, §21-306, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Written evidence establishes that the applicant's relationship with the deceased was as a:
Spouse of the deceased licensee;
Blood relative to the first degree of consanguinity; or
Current officer or surviving partner in the business operating the food service facility.
A local health department:
Shall issue a mobile reciprocity license:
In accordance with Health-General Article, §21-304, Annotated Code of Maryland;
To a mobile food service facility that:
Holds a valid license from the county of origin;
Is operating in the jurisdiction; and
Is operating within 90 miles of its base of operations, which shall be located in Maryland.

Shall provide copies of inspection or other supporting documentation for a mobile food service facility with a base of operations within the jurisdiction of the local health department to the jurisdiction in which the mobile food service facility is seeking a mobile reciprocity license;
May inspect the mobile food service facility during operation in the jurisdiction after a mobile reciprocity license has been issued;
May suspend a mobile reciprocity license for not maintaining a valid license from the county of origin until such time that the county of origin license is renewed;
May issue a violation of this regulation as set forth in Regulation .35 of this chapter; and
Shall notify all known Maryland jurisdictions which license the mobile food service facility if:
Any fines are issued to a mobile reciprocity licensee; or
Enforcement action is taken against a mobile reciprocity licensee under §J(3) of this regulation.
A mobile reciprocity license:
May not exceed $300; and
Is valid for a period of 1 year.
The person-in-charge shall permit a representative of the approving authority to:
Enter a food service facility at a reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this chapter; and
Examine the records of the facility that pertain to information regarding food and supplies purchased, received, or used.

The person-in-charge shall inform the approving authority of, and keep confidential, a food ingredient or a recipe that the person-in-charge considers a trade secret, except as provided in §C of this regulation.
The person-in-charge shall furnish information to the approving authority regarding a food ingredient or recipe that the person-in-charge considers a trade secret if:
An immediate and substantial danger to public health exists involving the food ingredient or recipe; or
The approving authority determines that the information about the food ingredient or recipe is necessary to conduct a foodborne disease investigation.

The approving authority shall maintain the confidentiality of trade secret information in accordance with State Government Article, §10-617, and Health-General Article, §21-259, Annotated Code of Maryland.
When an inspection of a food service facility is made, the approving authority shall:
Document:
The inspection results on an inspection report form provided by the Department; and
On the report:
Conditions found that violate the provisions of this chapter; and
Critical item violations, noted separately from all other violations;
Furnish one copy of the inspection report to the person-in-charge of the facility; and
Make the completed inspection report form available for public disclosure in accordance with State Government Article, §10-611—10-628, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Food Service Facility Inspections — Types and Frequencies.
section.text: The approving authority shall ensure that:

para.text: The following types of inspections are conducted:
A comprehensive inspection that contains:
A monitoring inspection as set forth in §A(2) of this regulation;
A HACCP compliance inspection as set forth in §A(3) of this regulation; and
An inspection of the physical facility to ensure compliance with the applicable sections of this chapter, including those governing:
Floors;
Walls;
Ceilings;
Lighting;
Ventilation;
Hoods;
Food equipment;
Toxic substances and cleaning supplies storage and use;
Cleaning, rinsing, and sanitizing;
Mechanical warewashers;
Insects, rodents, birds, or other animals;
Trash disposal;
Hand sinks;
Bathroom fixtures; and
Backflow and backsiphonage prevention;
A monitoring inspection that contains:
An inspection for compliance with critical items as:
Defined in Regulation .02B(19) of this chapter; and
Outlined in §C of this regulation;
A menu review to determine whether the existing priority assessment is correct; and
An evaluation of the physical facility to ensure that food is protected; and
A HACCP compliance inspection that contains:
An inspection for compliance with Regulation .34 of this chapter;
A comparison of the HACCP plan on site to the current menu;
An evaluation of the food preparation in progress to ensure that each CCP:
Is properly identified;
Is monitored according to the procedures contained in the HACCP plan; and
Has a corrective action that is implemented according to procedures contained in the HACCP plan;
Verification that the procedures used to monitor each CCP are accurate; and
Action to:
Enforce compliance with the HACCP plan; or
Have the existing HACCP plan revised to comply with Regulation .33E and F of this chapter;
The person-in-charge is in compliance with critical items when the person-in-charge:
Receives food from approved sources;
Protects food from adulteration;
Ensures that an individual who works with food:
Washes hands as necessary to protect food and food contact surfaces from contamination; and
Is excluded if ill as set forth in Regulation .14A and B of this chapter;
Cools potentially hazardous food:
As set forth in Regulation .11A—C of this chapter; and
In equipment that complies with Regulation .15 of this chapter;
Maintains potentially hazardous food:
Hot:
At hot holding temperatures as set forth in Regulation .06B(7) of this chapter; and
In equipment that complies with Regulation .15 of this chapter; or
Cold:
At refrigeration temperatures as set forth in Regulation .06B(7) of this chapter; and
In equipment that complies with Regulation .15 of this chapter;
Cooks and reheats potentially hazardous food:
As set forth in Regulations .10 and .11D of this chapter; and
In equipment that complies with Regulation .15 of this chapter;
Provides an adequate supply of potable water for:
Food preparation;
Hand washing;
Utensil washing;
Toilet facilities; and
Facility sanitation; and
Properly discharges sewage as set forth in Regulation .18F and G of this chapter;
A food service facility is inspected:
As needed for the enforcement of this chapter;
When a high priority food service facility:
At a minimum frequency of three times per year, one at every 4-month interval;
Except as provided in §D of this regulation, using:
A comprehensive inspection; and
Two monitoring inspections; and
That operates fewer than 12 months in a year, using one comprehensive inspection:
Per operating season if the operating season is less than 4 months; or
During each 4 month interval if the operating season is 4 months or greater;
When a moderate priority food service facility:
At a minimum of two times per year, one every 6 months;
Except as provided in §D of this regulation, using:
A comprehensive inspection; and
A monitoring inspection; and
That operates fewer than 12 months a year, using a comprehensive inspection during each period of 6 months or less;
When a low priority food service facility, using a comprehensive inspection at a minimum of once every 2 years except that a HACCP compliance inspection is not required;
When a temporary food service facility, using a monitoring inspection as set forth in Regulation .30A(2) of this chapter during each licensure period; and
When a seasonal farmer’s market producer sampling food service facility, using a monitoring inspection:
A minimum of two times per year, once every 6-month interval;
Except as provided in §D of this regulation; and
That operates fewer than 12 months in a year:
Per operating season if the operating season is less than 6 months; or
During each 6-month interval if the operating season is 6 months or greater; and
A food service facility is inspected as soon as possible when the food service facility has been associated with foodborne illness, using a:
HACCP compliance inspection that focuses on the food implicated with illness; and
Upon completion of the HACCP compliance inspection, either a:
Comprehensive inspection; or
Monitoring inspection.

section.heading: Time Period for Correction of Violations.

para.text: The person-in-charge shall correct:
Critical item violations immediately;
Other violations except as provided in §A(3) of this regulation within:
30 days of the inspection; or
Another time period specified by the approving authority based on applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances; and
Other violations at a temporary food service facility within:
24 hours of the inspection; or
Another time period specified by the approving authority based on applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances.
The approving authority may modify the specified time period for correcting a violation if the person-in-charge:
Submits a written schedule of compliance within a time frame for correcting a violation that is acceptable to the approving authority; and
There is no immediate or substantial danger to public health.

section.heading: Required Postings.
section.text: The person-in-charge shall ensure that a food service facility:

para.text: That prepares food and provides seating for patrons posts a diagram on the use of manual maneuvers to prevent asphyxiation due to choking, in accordance with Health-General Article, §21-326, Annotated Code of Maryland; and

Displays prominently in the staff area of the food establishment a poster related to food allergy awareness that includes information regarding the risk of an allergic reaction, in accordance with Health-General Article, §21-330.2(a), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that plans and specifications are submitted to and approved by the approving authority before a food establishment is:
Constructed;
Remodeled; or
Materially altered.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that the information submitted to the approving authority includes:
A scale drawing of the proposed facility that identifies the layout and arrangement of work areas and the location of all equipment;
A description of:
Materials to be used for interior finishes;
The layout and types of lighting to be used;
The proposed ventilation system; and
Methods and facilities for trash storage and disposal;
A plumbing diagram, including specifications of the method of sewage disposal and the source of potable water;
A complete list of specifications for the proposed food equipment;
A menu or other written description of the foods to be prepared or served;
General food handling information and procedures for:
Receiving;
Storage;
Thawing; and
Preparation;
A list of foods that will be:
Prepared in advance of service; or
Distributed off premises;
A description of the food systems that will be used, such as:
Cook-hot hold-serve;
Cook-cool-reheat-hot hold-serve; and
Cook-cool-cold hold-serve; and
Any other information that is required by the approving authority to ascertain compliance of the plans and specifications with all applicable State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances.
The approving authority shall:
Conduct a priority assessment of the facility based upon the information obtained in §B of this regulation;
Classify each food service facility as a:
High priority facility;
Moderate priority facility; or
Low priority facility;
Designate as a high priority facility, a facility that:
Is a health care facility; or
Serves potentially hazardous food that is prepared:
A day or more in advance of service; or
Using food preparation methods that require the food to pass through the temperature range of 41°F to 135°F two or more times before service, such as cooking, cooling, and then reheating;
Designate as a moderate priority facility, a facility that serves potentially hazardous food:
That is prepared using methods that require the food to pass through the temperature range of 41°F to 135°F not more than one time before service, such as cooking, hot holding, and then serving; or
That is cut, assembled, or packaged on the premises, such as meats; and
Designate as a low priority facility, a facility that serves:
Commercially packaged potentially hazardous foods directly to the consumer;
Non-potentially hazardous food that is cut, assembled, or packaged on the premises, such as candy, popcorn, and baked goods; or
Hand dipped ice cream.

Except for a temporary food service facility, the person-in-charge shall ensure that a HACCP plan is submitted to the approving authority for each high or moderate priority facility as specified in §C of this regulation.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that the HACCP plan includes the:
Identification of each CCP;
Critical limits for each CCP;
Monitoring procedures at each CCP;
Corrective action that will be taken if there is a loss of control at a CCP due to:
Employee error;
Equipment malfunction;
Power failure; or
Any other factor that causes loss of control at a CCP;
Verification procedures that will ensure proper monitoring of each CCP, such as:
Calibration of cooking and holding equipment and thermometers; and
Review of records such as temperature logs;
Written procedures for employee training in HACCP plan procedures; and
A list of the food service equipment that will be used at each CCP.
The person-in-charge shall construct the HACCP plan by:
Listing, for each CCP, the:
Menu items controlled by the CCP;
Equipment used; and
Monitoring, corrective action, and verification procedures;
Incorporation of the requirements of §E of this regulation into a recipe or preparation instructions; or
Another way that meets the requirements of §E of this regulation.

section.heading: HACCP Plan Compliance.
section.text: The person-in-charge of a high or moderate priority food service facility shall ensure that:

para.text: A HACCP plan is:
In compliance with Regulation .33E and F of this chapter;
Within the food preparation area during operation;
Readily accessible to employees at all times; and
Updated as follows:
When a change in food processes or procedures change one or more CCP; and
At least once every 5 years;
An employee involved in food preparation is trained in the HACCP procedures; and
Changes to the HACCP plan are submitted to the approving authority before implementation of the HACCP plan.
The approving authority shall ensure that when a food service facility is found in violation of any provision of this chapter, the licensee is notified:
Of the specific findings;
Of a specific date by which the licensee shall correct the violations or deficiencies; and
That, if the licensee fails to correct the violation by the date specified, the approving authority may suspend or revoke the license.

When a person is violating any provision of this chapter, the approving authority may serve the person with a written order pursuant to Health-General Article, §21-318 or 21-261, Annotated Code of Maryland, directing the person to abate the violation within a specified time period.

When an inspection indicates that an immediate and substantial danger to public health exists and requires emergency action at a facility operated by an excluded organization, the approving authority may seek injunctive relief as provided in Health-General Article, §§21-1214 and 21-1215, Annotated Code of Maryland.

The approving authority shall ensure that an opportunity for a hearing is provided to a person served with an order, pursuant to State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
In order to preserve a right to a hearing under any provision of this regulation, a person shall:
Make a request for a hearing in writing; and
Submit the request to the approving authority that issued the order or inspection report:
Within 10 days of receipt of the order;
Sooner if specified in the order; or
Within 24 hours if:
The violation requires immediate correction or correction within 24 hours; or
The facility is a temporary food service facility.
The approving authority shall suspend or revoke the license of a food service facility if the licensee fails or neglects to:
Correct a violation within the specified time period;
Comply with an approved written schedule of compliance;
Correct a critical item immediately; or
Correct a violation in a temporary food service facility within 24 hours.
The approving authority shall ensure that an action to suspend or revoke a license:
Complies with the provisions of:
State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Health-General Article, §21-315, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
The person against whom the action is contemplated is given an opportunity for a hearing in accordance with Health-General Article, §21-316, Annotated Code of Maryland.

When an immediate and substantial danger is found to exist to public health, safety, or welfare that imperatively requires emergency action, pursuant to State Government Article, §10-226(c)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland, the:
Approving authority shall:
Summarily suspend the license at a food service facility;
Order the food service facility to cease operation immediately; and
Promptly provide the licensee with:
A written notice of suspension of the license;
The reasons for the suspension; and
An opportunity to be heard; and
Person-in-charge shall immediately cease the operation of the food service facility.

The person-in-charge shall ensure that a food service facility that has been required under the provisions of this regulation to cease operations does not resume operations until a reinspection by the approving authority shows that the condition or conditions responsible for the requirement to cease operations no longer exists.

The approving authority shall ensure that appropriate steps are taken to ensure that the licensee ceases operation of the food service facility upon suspension or revocation of the license, including:
Taking and keeping physical possession of the license until the license is reinstated;
Posting a sign on the facility door stating that the license has been suspended or revoked by the approving authority; or
Taking another measure within the law that will ensure that the facility does not operate.

A person whose food service facility license has been suspended or revoked may apply for reinspection and reinstatement of the license by submitting to the approving authority a written request that details the actions taken by the person to correct each violation of a food statute or regulation that caused the suspension or revocation.

section.heading: Foodborne Disease Investigation and Control.
section.text: The approving authority shall ensure that:

para.text: When there is reasonable cause to suspect foodborne disease transmission from a food service facility employee:
A morbidity history of the suspected employee is taken;
An investigation is conducted; and
The appropriate follow-up action is taken that may include:
Immediate exclusion of the employee from all food handling positions within the facility; and
Immediate closing of the food service facility until medical and epidemiological evidence shows that the likelihood of further foodborne disease transmission is low; and
An investigation, a report, and the control of a foodborne disease outbreak is conducted in accordance with the provisions of COMAR 10.06.01.

section.heading: Sampling, Detention, and Condemnation of Food.

para.text: Sample and examine food as often as necessary for enforcement of this chapter;
Sample food in accordance with Health-General Article, §§21-249 and 21-251, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Take action on a food in accordance with Health-General Article, §§21-211, 21-253, and 21-254, Annotated Code of Maryland, by:
Issuing a detention order;
Destroying the food; or
Making the food unusable for consumption.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: A person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or refuses, neglects, or fails to comply with the provisions and requirements of this chapter is subject to:

para.text: Penalties, fines, and imprisonment as set forth in Health-General Article, §§21-1214 and 21-1215, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Penalties and fines as provided by local law, ordinance, or regulation in accordance with Health-General Article, §21-309.2(e)(3), Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Federal Compliance.
section.text: In addition to the other requirements set forth in this chapter, the person in charge shall ensure that the food service facility meets all of the requirements applicable to food sources, storage, preparation, and service that are set forth at:

para.text: 21 CFR, as amended;
9 CFR, as amended; and
21 U.S.C. §343, as amended.

The owner or operator of a micro market may not be required to have a person-in-charge present during the hours of operation of the micro market if the micro market meets the requirements of this regulation.
Food sold at a micro market shall:
Be commercially prepackaged food or ready-to-eat food;
Be prepackaged in tamper-evident packaging; and
Contain all the following information on the packaging label:
Nutrition information required by the federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act;
A freshness or expiration date; and
Any other information required by Maryland law.
Refrigerated or frozen food sold at a micro market shall be stored and displayed in a refrigerator, refrigerated cooler, or freezer that:
Maintains an internal temperature of 41°F or lower;
Has self-closing doors;
Has doors that allow the food on display to be viewed without opening the door to the refrigerator, refrigerated cooler, or freezer; and

Has an automated self-locking feature that prevents a consumer from accessing the food on the occurrence of any condition that results in the failure of the refrigerator, refrigerated cooler, or freezer to maintain the internal temperature required under Regulation .06 of this chapter.

Signage and Notice. The owner or operator of a micro market shall post a sign that is clearly visible to the consumer near the micro market entryway or while using the electronic payment device that includes the following information:
The name of the owner or operator of the micro market to whom complaints and comments regarding the micro market may be addressed;
The business mailing address of the owner or operator;
The business telephone number of the owner or operator; and
The email address and website address of the owner or operator, if applicable.
Security. The owner or operator of a micro market:
May secure the products and premises of a micro market by the use of video surveillance that:
Operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week;
Records consumers viewing, selecting, handling, and purchasing products from the micro market; and
Provides sufficient resolution to identify consumers described in §E(1)(b) of this regulation; and
Shall ensure that video surveillance recordings made under §E(1) of this regulation are:
Maintained by the owner for 14 days after the date of the video recording; and
Made available for inspection by the appropriate health or law enforcement agency on the request of the agency within 24 hours from the time the request is received by the owner or operator.
Record Keeping. The owner or operator of a micro market shall ensure that:
In the event of a failure of an automated self-locking unit, records are kept for:
The repair or replacement of the failed unit in the form of receipts or a completed service order; and
All products in the unit at the time of the failure and include:
Product description; and
Quantity of products discarded or destroyed;
Service receipts for the repair or replacement of the failed unit and product destruction shall be kept for a minimum of 90 days; and
All records are available for review upon request.
